<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Abraham Lincoln</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">President of the United States from 1861 to 1865</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the president of the United States. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln_(disambiguation)" title="Abraham Lincoln (disambiguation)">Abraham Lincoln (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Abe Lincoln" redirects here. For the jazz musician, see <a href="/wiki/Abe_Lincoln_(musician)" title="Abe Lincoln (musician)">Abe Lincoln (musician)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

</div></td></tr><tr><td class="infobox-below" colspan="2" style="border-top: 1px solid right; font-size: 95%"><div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1045330069">.mw-parser-output .sidebar{width:22em;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 1em;background:#f8f9fa;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%;border-collapse:collapse;display:table}body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .sidebar-left{float:left;clear:left;margin:0.5em 1em 1em 0}.mw-parser-output .sidebar-none{float:none;clear:both;margin:0.5em 1em 1em 0}.mw-parser-output .sidebar-outer-title{padding:0 0.4em .mw-parser-output .sidebar{width:100%!important;clear:both;float:none!important;margin-left:0!important;margin-right:0!important}}</style><table class="sidebar nomobile vcard hlist" style="border: 4px <td style="background: #002466; vertical-align:middle; padding:5px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_O-77_matte_collodion_print.jpg"><img alt="Abraham Lincoln O-77 matte collodion print.jpg" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2835" data-file-width="2200" decoding="async" height="97" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Abraham_Lincoln_O-77_matte_collodion_print.jpg/75px-Abraham_Lincoln_O-77_matte_collodion_print.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Abraham_Lincoln_O-77_matte_collodion_print.jpg/113px-Abraham_Lincoln_O-77_matte_collodion_print.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Abraham_Lincoln_O-77_matte_collodion_print.jpg/150px-Abraham_Lincoln_O-77_matte_collodion_print.jpg 2x" width="75"/></a></td>

<img alt="Seal of the President of the United States" data-file-height="2425" data-file-width="2424" decoding="async" height="70" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg/70px-Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg/105px-Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg/140px-Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="70"/></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar" style="text-align:center;"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1063604349">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Abraham_Lincoln_series" title="Template:Abraham Lincoln series"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Abraham_Lincoln_series" title="Template talk:Abraham Lincoln series"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Abraham_Lincoln_series&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Abraham Lincoln</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ŋ/: 'ng' in 'sing'">ŋ</span><span title="'k' in 'kind'">k</span><span title="/ən/: 'on' in 'button'">ən</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">LINK</span>-ən</i></a>; February 12, 1809 – April 15, 1865) was an American lawyer and statesman who served as the 16th <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">president of the United States</a> from 1861 until <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Assassination of Abraham Lincoln">his assassination</a> in 1865. Lincoln led the nation through the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a> and succeeded in preserving the <a href="/wiki/Union_(American_Civil_War)" title="Union (American Civil War)">Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States" title="Abolitionism in the United States">abolishing</a> <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States" title="Slavery in the United States">slavery</a>, bolstering the <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Federal government of the United States">federal government</a>, and modernizing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._economy" title="U.S. economy">U.S. economy</a>.
</p><p>Lincoln was born into poverty in a log cabin in <a href="/wiki/Kentucky" title="Kentucky">Kentucky</a> and was raised on the <a href="/wiki/American_frontier" title="American frontier">frontier</a>, primarily in <a href="/wiki/Indiana" title="Indiana">Indiana</a>. He was self-educated and became a lawyer, <a href="/wiki/Whig_Party_(United_States)" title="Whig Party (United States)">Whig Party</a> leader, <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">Illinois</a> state <a href="/wiki/Illinois_House_of_Representatives" title="Illinois House of Representatives">legislator</a>, and U.S. Congressman <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_representatives_from_Illinois" title="List of United States representatives from Illinois">from Illinois</a>. In 1849, he returned to his successful law practice in central Illinois.  In 1854 he was angered by the <a href="/wiki/Kansas%E2%80%93Nebraska_Act" title="Kansas–Nebraska Act">Kansas–Nebraska Act</a> that opened the territories to slavery, and re-entered politics. He soon became a leader of the new <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="History of the Republican Party (United States)">Republican Party</a>. He reached a national audience in the <a href="/wiki/Lincoln%E2%80%93Douglas_debates" title="Lincoln–Douglas debates">1858 Senate campaign debates</a> against <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stephen_Douglas" title="Stephen Douglas">Stephen Douglas</a>. Lincoln ran for President <a href="/wiki/1860_United_States_presidential_election" title="1860 United States presidential election">in 1860</a>, sweeping the <a href="/wiki/Northern_United_States" title="Northern United States">North</a> to gain victory. Pro-slavery elements in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_United_States" title="Southern United States">South</a> viewed his election as a threat to slavery, and Southern states began <a href="/wiki/Secession" title="Secession">seceding from the Union</a>. During this time the newly formed <a href="/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America" title="Confederate States of America">Confederate States of America</a> began seizing federal military bases in the south. Just over one month after Lincoln assumed the presidency, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Confederate_States" title="Confederate States">Confederate States</a> <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Sumter" title="Battle of Fort Sumter">attacked Fort Sumter</a>, a U.S. fort in South Carolina. Following the bombardment, Lincoln mobilized forces to suppress the rebellion and restore the Union.
</p><p>Lincoln, a <a href="/wiki/Moderate_Republicans_(Reconstruction_era)" title="Moderate Republicans (Reconstruction era)">moderate Republican</a>, had to navigate a contentious array of factions with friends and opponents from both the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic</a> and Republican parties. His allies, the <a href="/wiki/War_Democrat" title="War Democrat">War Democrats</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Radical_Republicans" title="Radical Republicans">Radical Republicans</a>, demanded harsh treatment of the Southern Confederates. Anti-war Democrats (called "<a href="/wiki/Copperhead_(politics)" title="Copperhead (politics)">Copperheads</a>") despised Lincoln, and irreconcilable pro-Confederate elements plotted his assassination. He managed the factions by exploiting their mutual enmity, carefully distributing political patronage, and by appealing to the American people. His <a href="/wiki/Gettysburg_Address" title="Gettysburg Address">Gettysburg Address</a> came to be seen as one of the greatest and most influential statements of American national purpose. Lincoln closely supervised the strategy and tactics in the war effort, including the selection of generals, and implemented a <a href="/wiki/Union_blockade" title="Union blockade">naval blockade</a> of the South's trade. He suspended <i><a href="/wiki/Habeas_corpus" title="Habeas corpus">habeas corpus</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Maryland" title="Maryland">Maryland</a>, and he averted British intervention by defusing the <a href="/wiki/Trent_Affair" title="Trent Affair"><i>Trent</i> Affair</a>. In 1863 he issued the <a href="/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation" title="Emancipation Proclamation">Emancipation Proclamation</a>, which declared the slaves in the states "in rebellion" to be free. It also directed the Army and Navy to "recognize and maintain the freedom of such persons" and to receive them "into the armed service of the United States." Lincoln also pressured <a href="/wiki/Border_states_(American_Civil_War)" title="Border states (American Civil War)">border states</a> to outlaw slavery, and he promoted the <a href="/wiki/Thirteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution">Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution</a>, which upon its ratification abolished slavery.
</p><p>Lincoln managed his own successful <a href="/wiki/1864_United_States_presidential_election" title="1864 United States presidential election">re-election campaign</a>. He sought to heal the war-torn nation through reconciliation. On April 14, 1865, just days after <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Appomattox_Court_House" title="Battle of Appomattox Court House">the war's end at Appomattox</a>, he was attending a play at <a href="/wiki/Ford%27s_Theatre" title="Ford's Theatre">Ford's Theatre</a> in Washington, D.C., with his wife <a href="/wiki/Mary_Todd_Lincoln" title="Mary Todd Lincoln">Mary</a> when he was fatally shot by Confederate sympathizer <a href="/wiki/John_Wilkes_Booth" title="John Wilkes Booth">John Wilkes Booth</a>. Abraham Lincoln is remembered as a <a href="/wiki/Martyr" title="Martyr">martyr</a> and a national hero for his wartime leadership and for his efforts to preserve the Union and abolish slavery. Lincoln is often <a href="/wiki/Historical_rankings_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#Scholar_survey_summary" title="Historical rankings of presidents of the United States">ranked</a> in both popular and scholarly polls as the greatest president in American history.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-5"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</div>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family_and_childhood">Family and childhood</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Early_life_and_career_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Early life and career of Abraham Lincoln">Early life and career of Abraham Lincoln</a></div>
<p>Abraham Lincoln was born on February 12, 1809, the second child of <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Lincoln" title="Thomas Lincoln">Thomas Lincoln</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Lincoln" title="Nancy Lincoln">Nancy Hanks Lincoln</a>, in a log cabin on <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln_Birthplace_National_Historical_Park" title="Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park">Sinking Spring Farm</a> near <a href="/wiki/Hodgenville,_Kentucky" title="Hodgenville, Kentucky">Hodgenville, Kentucky</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199620–22_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199620–22-3">[2]</a></sup> He was a descendant of <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Lincoln" title="Samuel Lincoln">Samuel Lincoln</a>, an Englishman who migrated from <a href="/wiki/Hingham,_Norfolk" title="Hingham, Norfolk">Hingham, Norfolk</a>, to its namesake, <a href="/wiki/Hingham,_Massachusetts" title="Hingham, Massachusetts">Hingham, Massachusetts</a>, in 1638. The family then migrated west, passing through <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">Virginia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarren20173–4_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarren20173–4-4">[3]</a></sup> Lincoln's paternal grandparents, his namesake <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln_(captain)" title="Abraham Lincoln (captain)">Captain Abraham Lincoln</a> and wife Bathsheba (née Herring) moved the family from Virginia to <a href="/wiki/Jefferson_County,_Kentucky" title="Jefferson County, Kentucky">Jefferson County, Kentucky</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[b]</a></sup> The captain was killed in an <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Indian_War" title="Northwest Indian War">Indian raid</a> in 1786.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarren20174_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarren20174-7">[5]</a></sup> His children, including eight-year-old Thomas, Abraham's father, witnessed the attack.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199621_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199621-8">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[c]</a></sup> Thomas then worked at odd jobs in Kentucky and <a href="/wiki/Tennessee" title="Tennessee">Tennessee</a> before the family settled in <a href="/wiki/Hardin_County,_Kentucky" title="Hardin County, Kentucky">Hardin County, Kentucky</a>, in the early 1800s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199621_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199621-8">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Hanks_Lincoln_heritage" title="Nancy Hanks Lincoln heritage">heritage of Lincoln's mother Nancy</a> remains unclear, but it is widely assumed that she was the daughter of Lucy Hanks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBartelt200879_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBartelt200879-11">[8]</a></sup> Thomas and Nancy married on June 12, 1806, in Washington County, and moved to <a href="/wiki/Elizabethtown,_Kentucky" title="Elizabethtown, Kentucky">Elizabethtown, Kentucky</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarren20179_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarren20179-12">[9]</a></sup> They had three children: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sarah_Lincoln_Grigsby" title="Sarah Lincoln Grigsby">Sarah</a>, Abraham, and Thomas, who died as an infant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarren20179–10_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarren20179–10-13">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>Thomas Lincoln bought or leased farms in Kentucky before losing all but 200 acres (81 ha) of his land in court disputes over <a href="/wiki/Title_(property)" title="Title (property)">property titles</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandburg192620_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandburg192620-14">[11]</a></sup> In 1816, the family moved to <a href="/wiki/Indiana" title="Indiana">Indiana</a> where the land surveys and titles were more reliable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarren201713_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarren201713-15">[12]</a></sup> Indiana was a <a href="/wiki/Slave_states_and_free_states" title="Slave states and free states">"free" (non-slaveholding)</a> territory, and they settled in an "unbroken forest"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarren201726_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarren201726-16">[13]</a></sup> in Hurricane Township, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Perry_County,_Indiana" title="History of Perry County, Indiana">Perry County, Indiana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarren201716,_43_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarren201716,_43-17">[14]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[d]</a></sup> In 1860, Lincoln noted that the family's move to Indiana was "partly on account of slavery", but mainly due to land title difficulties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandburg192620Donald199623–24_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandburg192620Donald199623–24-20">[16]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Log_Cabin_at_the_Lincoln_Living_Historical_Farm.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3168" data-file-width="4752" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Log_Cabin_at_the_Lincoln_Living_Historical_Farm.jpg/220px-Log_Cabin_at_the_Lincoln_Living_Historical_Farm.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Log_Cabin_at_the_Lincoln_Living_Historical_Farm.jpg/330px-Log_Cabin_at_the_Lincoln_Living_Historical_Farm.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Log_Cabin_at_the_Lincoln_Living_Historical_Farm.jpg/440px-Log_Cabin_at_the_Lincoln_Living_Historical_Farm.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Log_Cabin_at_the_Lincoln_Living_Historical_Farm.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The farm site where Lincoln grew up in <a href="/wiki/Spencer_County,_Indiana" title="Spencer County, Indiana">Spencer County, Indiana</a></div></div></div>
<p>In Kentucky and Indiana, Thomas worked as a farmer, cabinetmaker, and carpenter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBartelt200834,_156_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBartelt200834,_156-21">[17]</a></sup> At various times, he owned farms, livestock, and town lots, paid taxes, sat on juries, appraised estates, and served on county patrols. Thomas and Nancy were members of a <a href="/wiki/Separate_Baptists" title="Separate Baptists">Separate Baptists</a> church, which forbade alcohol, dancing, and slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199622–24_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199622–24-22">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Overcoming financial challenges, Thomas in 1827 obtained <a href="/wiki/Clear_title" title="Clear title">clear title</a> to 80 acres (32 ha) in Indiana, an area which became the <a href="/wiki/Little_Pigeon_Creek_Community" title="Little Pigeon Creek Community">Little Pigeon Creek Community</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBartelt200824,_104_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBartelt200824,_104-23">[19]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Mother.27s_death"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Mother's_death">Mother's death</span></h3>
<p>On October 5, 1818, Nancy Lincoln died from <a href="/wiki/Milk_sickness" title="Milk sickness">milk sickness</a>, leaving 11-year-old Sarah in charge of a household including her father, 9-year-old Abraham, and Nancy's 19-year-old orphan cousin, Dennis Hanks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBartelt200822–23,_77_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBartelt200822–23,_77-24">[20]</a></sup> Ten years later, on January 20, 1828, Sarah died while giving birth to a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stillborn" title="Stillborn">stillborn</a> son, devastating Lincoln.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199634,_116_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199634,_116-25">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>On December 2, 1819, Thomas married <a href="/wiki/Sarah_Bush_Lincoln" title="Sarah Bush Lincoln">Sarah Bush Johnston</a>, a widow from Elizabethtown, Kentucky, with three children of her own.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBartelt200823,_83_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBartelt200823,_83-26">[22]</a></sup> Abraham became close to his stepmother and called her "Mother".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199626–27_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199626–27-27">[23]</a></sup> Lincoln disliked the hard labor associated with farm life. His family even said he was lazy, for all his "reading, scribbling, writing, ciphering, writing Poetry, etc.".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite200925,_31,_47_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite200925,_31,_47-28">[24]</a></sup> His stepmother acknowledged he did not enjoy "physical labor", but loved to read.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBartelt200866_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBartelt200866-29">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education_and_move_to_Illinois">Education and move to Illinois</span></h3>
<p>Lincoln was largely self-educated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBartelt200810,_33_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBartelt200810,_33-30">[26]</a></sup> His formal schooling was from <a href="/wiki/Itinerant_teacher" title="Itinerant teacher">itinerant teachers</a>. It included two short stints in Kentucky, where he learned to read but probably not to write, at age seven,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199623_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199623-31">[27]</a></sup> and in Indiana, where he went to school sporadically due to farm chores, for a total of fewer than 12 months in aggregate by the age of 15.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199629_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199629-32">[28]</a></sup> He persisted as an avid reader and retained a lifelong interest in learning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMadison2014110_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMadison2014110-33">[29]</a></sup> Family, neighbors, and schoolmates recalled that his reading included the <a href="/wiki/King_James_Version" title="King James Version">King James Bible</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aesop%27s_Fables" title="Aesop's Fables">Aesop's Fables</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Bunyan" title="John Bunyan">John Bunyan</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Pilgrim%27s_Progress" title="The Pilgrim's Progress">The Pilgrim's Progress</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Defoe" title="Daniel Defoe">Daniel Defoe</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Robinson_Crusoe" title="Robinson Crusoe">Robinson Crusoe</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Autobiography_of_Benjamin_Franklin" title="The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin">The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199629–31,_38–43_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199629–31,_38–43-34">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a teen, Lincoln took responsibility for chores and customarily gave his father all earnings from work outside the home until he was 21.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199630–33_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199630–33-35">[31]</a></sup> Lincoln was tall, strong, and athletic, and became adept at using an ax.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarren2017134–135_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarren2017134–135-36">[32]</a></sup> He was an active wrestler during his youth and trained in the rough <a href="/wiki/Catch_wrestling" title="Catch wrestling">catch-as-catch-can</a> style (also known as catch wrestling). He became county wrestling champion at the age of 21.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[33]</a></sup> He gained a reputation for strength and audacity after winning a wrestling match with the renowned leader of ruffians known as "the Clary's Grove Boys".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199641_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199641-38">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 1830, fearing another milk sickness outbreak, several members of the extended Lincoln family, including Abraham, moved west to Illinois, a free state, and settled in <a href="/wiki/Macon_County,_Illinois" title="Macon County, Illinois">Macon County</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199636_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199636-39">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[e]</a></sup> Abraham then became increasingly distant from Thomas, in part due to his father's lack of education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBartelt200871_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBartelt200871-42">[37]</a></sup> In 1831, as Thomas and other family prepared to move to a <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Log_Cabin_State_Historic_Site" title="Lincoln Log Cabin State Historic Site">new homestead</a> in <a href="/wiki/Coles_County,_Illinois" title="Coles County, Illinois">Coles County, Illinois</a>, Abraham struck out on his own.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOates197415–17_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOates197415–17-43">[38]</a></sup> He made his home in <a href="/wiki/Lincoln%27s_New_Salem" title="Lincoln's New Salem">New Salem, Illinois</a>, for six years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThomas200823–53_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas200823–53-44">[39]</a></sup> Lincoln and some friends took goods by <a href="/wiki/Flatboat" title="Flatboat">flatboat</a> to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Orleans,_Louisiana" title="New Orleans, Louisiana">New Orleans, Louisiana</a>, where he was first exposed to slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandburg192622–23Donald199638_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandburg192622–23Donald199638-45">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1865, Lincoln was asked how he came to acquire his rhetorical skills. He answered that in the practice of law he frequently came across the word "demonstrate" but had insufficient understanding of the term. So, he left Springfield for his father's home to study until he "could give any proposition in the six books of <a href="/wiki/Euclid" title="Euclid">Euclid</a> [here, referencing Euclid's <a href="/wiki/Euclid%27s_Elements" title="Euclid's Elements"><i>Elements</i></a>] at sight."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllenberg2021_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllenberg2021-46">[41]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Marriage_and_children">Marriage and children</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_family" title="Lincoln family">Lincoln family</a>, <a href="/wiki/Health_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Health of Abraham Lincoln">Health of Abraham Lincoln</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sexuality_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Sexuality of Abraham Lincoln">Sexuality of Abraham Lincoln</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:364px;max-width:364px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:194px;max-width:194px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A%26TLincoln.jpg"><img alt="A seated Lincoln holding a book as his young son looks at it" data-file-height="3696" data-file-width="3351" decoding="async" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/A%26TLincoln.jpg/192px-A%26TLincoln.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/A%26TLincoln.jpg/288px-A%26TLincoln.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/A%26TLincoln.jpg/384px-A%26TLincoln.jpg 2x" width="192"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">1864 photo of President Lincoln with youngest son, <a href="/wiki/Tad_Lincoln" title="Tad Lincoln">Tad</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:166px;max-width:166px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mary_Todd_Lincoln2crop.jpg"><img alt="Black and white photo of Mary Todd Lincoln's shoulders and head" data-file-height="1803" data-file-width="1395" decoding="async" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Mary_Todd_Lincoln2crop.jpg/164px-Mary_Todd_Lincoln2crop.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Mary_Todd_Lincoln2crop.jpg/246px-Mary_Todd_Lincoln2crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Mary_Todd_Lincoln2crop.jpg/328px-Mary_Todd_Lincoln2crop.jpg 2x" width="164"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Mary_Todd_Lincoln" title="Mary Todd Lincoln">Mary Todd Lincoln</a>, wife of Abraham Lincoln, in 1861</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Lincoln's first romantic interest was <a href="/wiki/Ann_Rutledge" title="Ann Rutledge">Ann Rutledge</a>, whom he met when he moved to New Salem. By 1835, they were in a relationship but not formally engaged.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[42]</a></sup> She died on August 25, 1835, most likely of <a href="/wiki/Typhoid_fever" title="Typhoid fever">typhoid fever</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199655–58_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199655–58-48">[43]</a></sup> In the early 1830s, he met Mary Owens from Kentucky.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThomas200856–57,_69–70_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas200856–57,_69–70-49">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>Late in 1836, Lincoln agreed to a match with Owens if she returned to New Salem. Owens arrived that November and he courted her for a time; however, they both had second thoughts. On August 16, 1837, he wrote Owens a letter saying he would not blame her if she ended the relationship, and she never replied.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199667_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199667-50">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1839, Lincoln met <a href="/wiki/Mary_Todd_Lincoln" title="Mary Todd Lincoln">Mary Todd</a> in <a href="/wiki/Springfield,_Illinois" title="Springfield, Illinois">Springfield, Illinois</a>, and the following year they became engaged.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199680–86_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199680–86-51">[46]</a></sup> She was the daughter of <a href="/wiki/Robert_Smith_Todd" title="Robert Smith Todd">Robert Smith Todd</a>, a wealthy lawyer and businessman in <a href="/wiki/Lexington,_Kentucky" title="Lexington, Kentucky">Lexington, Kentucky</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambSwain20083_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambSwain20083-52">[47]</a></sup> A wedding set for January 1, 1841, was canceled at Lincoln's request, but they reconciled and married on November 4, 1842, in the Springfield mansion of Mary's sister.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandburg192646–51_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandburg192646–51-53">[48]</a></sup> While anxiously preparing for the nuptials, he was asked where he was going and replied, "To hell, I suppose."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199693_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199693-54">[49]</a></sup> In 1844, the couple bought <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Home_National_Historic_Site" title="Lincoln Home National Historic Site">a house</a> in Springfield near his law office. Mary kept house with the help of a hired servant and a relative.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBaker1989142_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaker1989142-55">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lincoln was an affectionate husband and father of four sons, though his work regularly kept him away from home. The oldest, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Todd_Lincoln" title="Robert Todd Lincoln">Robert Todd Lincoln</a>, was born in 1843 and was the only child to live to maturity. <a href="/wiki/Edward_Baker_Lincoln" title="Edward Baker Lincoln">Edward Baker Lincoln</a> (Eddie), born in 1846, died February 1, 1850, probably of tuberculosis. Lincoln's third son, <a href="/wiki/William_Wallace_Lincoln" title="William Wallace Lincoln">"Willie" Lincoln</a> was born on December 21, 1850, and died of a fever at the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a> on February 20, 1862. The youngest, <a href="/wiki/Tad_Lincoln" title="Tad Lincoln">Thomas "Tad" Lincoln</a>, was born on April 4, 1853, and survived his father but died of heart failure at age 18 on July 16, 1871.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009179–181,_476_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009179–181,_476-56">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[f]</a></sup> Lincoln "was remarkably fond of children"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009126_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009126-59">[53]</a></sup> and the Lincolns were not considered to be strict with their own.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBaker1989120_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaker1989120-60">[54]</a></sup> In fact, Lincoln's law partner <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_H._Herndon" title="William H. Herndon">William H. Herndon</a> would grow irritated when Lincoln brought his children to the law office. Their father, it seemed, was often too absorbed in his work to notice his children's behavior. Herndon recounted, "I have felt many and many a time that I wanted to wring their little necks, and yet out of respect for Lincoln I kept my mouth shut. Lincoln did not note what his children were doing or had done."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>The deaths of their sons, Eddie and Willie, had profound effects on both parents. Lincoln suffered from "<a href="/wiki/History_of_depression" title="History of depression">melancholy</a>", a condition now thought to be <a href="/wiki/Major_depressive_disorder" title="Major depressive disorder">clinical depression</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlanticoct2005_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-Atlanticoct2005-62">[56]</a></sup> Later in life, Mary struggled with the stresses of losing her husband and sons, and Robert committed her for a time to an asylum in 1875.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteers2010341_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteers2010341-63">[57]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_career_and_militia_service">Early career and militia service</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Early_life_and_career_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Early life and career of Abraham Lincoln">Early life and career of Abraham Lincoln</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln_in_the_Black_Hawk_War" title="Abraham Lincoln in the Black Hawk War">Abraham Lincoln in the Black Hawk War</a></div>
<p>During 1831 and 1832, Lincoln worked at a general store in <a href="/wiki/Lincoln%27s_New_Salem" title="Lincoln's New Salem">New Salem, Illinois</a>. In 1832 he declared his candidacy for the <a href="/wiki/Illinois_House_of_Representatives" title="Illinois House of Representatives">Illinois House of Representatives</a>, but interrupted his campaign to serve as a captain in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Illinois_Militia" title="Illinois Militia">Illinois Militia</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Black_Hawk_War" title="Black Hawk War">Black Hawk War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWinkle200186–95_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinkle200186–95-64">[58]</a></sup>  When Lincoln returned home from the <a href="/wiki/Black_Hawk_War" title="Black Hawk War">Black Hawk War</a>, he planned to become a blacksmith, but instead formed a partnership with William Berry, 21, with whom he purchased a New Salem general store on credit. Because a license was required to sell customers single beverages, Berry obtained bartending licenses for $7 each for Lincoln and himself, and in 1833 the store became a tavern as well. As licensed bartenders, Lincoln and Berry were able to sell spirits, including liquor, for 12 cents a pint. They offered a wide range of alcoholic beverages as well as food, including takeout dinners. But Berry became an alcoholic, was often too drunk to work, and Lincoln ended up running the store by himself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[59]</a></sup> Although the economy was booming, the business struggled and went into debt, causing Lincoln to sell his share.
</p><p>In his first campaign speech after returning from his military service, Lincoln observed a supporter in the crowd under attack, grabbed the assailant by his "neck and the seat of his trousers", and tossed him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199636_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199636-39">[35]</a></sup> In the campaign, Lincoln advocated for navigational improvements on the <a href="/wiki/Sangamon_River" title="Sangamon River">Sangamon River</a>. He could draw crowds as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raconteur" title="Raconteur">raconteur</a>, but lacked the requisite formal education, powerful friends, and money, and lost the election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[60]</a></sup> Lincoln finished eighth out of 13 candidates (the top four were elected), though he received 277 of the 300 votes cast in the New Salem precinct.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWinkle2001114–116_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinkle2001114–116-67">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lincoln served as New Salem's postmaster and later as county surveyor, but continued his voracious reading and decided to become a lawyer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zofia_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zofia-68">[62]</a></sup> Rather than studying in the office of an established attorney, as was the custom, Lincoln borrowed legal texts from attorneys <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Todd_Stuart" title="John Todd Stuart">John Todd Stuart</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Drummond_(judge)" title="Thomas Drummond (judge)">Thomas Drummond</a>, purchased books including <a href="/wiki/William_Blackstone" title="William Blackstone">Blackstone</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Commentaries_on_the_Laws_of_England" title="Commentaries on the Laws of England">Commentaries</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Chitty" title="Joseph Chitty">Chitty</a>'s <i>Pleadings</i>, and <a href="/wiki/Reading_law" title="Reading law">read law</a> on his own.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zofia_68-1"><a href="#cite_note-Zofia-68">[62]</a></sup> He later said of his legal education that "I studied with nobody."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199653–55_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199653–55-69">[63]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Illinois_state_legislature_.281834.E2.80.931842.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Illinois_state_legislature_(1834–1842)">Illinois state legislature (1834–1842)</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abes_House.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3240" data-file-width="4320" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Abes_House.JPG/220px-Abes_House.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Abes_House.JPG/330px-Abes_House.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Abes_House.JPG/440px-Abes_House.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abes_House.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lincoln's home in <a href="/wiki/Springfield,_Illinois" title="Springfield, Illinois">Springfield, Illinois</a></div></div></div>
<p>Lincoln's second state house campaign in 1834, this time as a <a href="/wiki/Whig_Party_(United_States)" title="Whig Party (United States)">Whig</a>, was a success over a powerful Whig opponent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite200959_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite200959-70">[64]</a></sup> Then followed his four terms in the <a href="/wiki/Illinois_House_of_Representatives" title="Illinois House of Representatives">Illinois House of Representatives</a> for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sangamon_County" title="Sangamon County">Sangamon County</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESimon1990283_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESimon1990283-71">[65]</a></sup> He championed construction of the <a href="/wiki/Illinois_and_Michigan_Canal" title="Illinois and Michigan Canal">Illinois and Michigan Canal</a>, and later was a Canal Commissioner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[66]</a></sup> He voted to expand suffrage beyond white landowners to all white males, but adopted a "free soil" stance opposing both slavery and <a href="/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States" title="Abolitionism in the United States">abolition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESimon1990130_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESimon1990130-73">[67]</a></sup> In 1837, he declared, "[The] Institution of slavery is founded on both injustice and bad policy, but the promulgation of abolition doctrines tends rather to increase than abate its evils."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996134_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996134-74">[68]</a></sup> He echoed <a href="/wiki/Henry_Clay" title="Henry Clay">Henry Clay</a>'s support for the <a href="/wiki/American_Colonization_Society" title="American Colonization Society">American Colonization Society</a> which advocated a program of abolition in conjunction with settling freed slaves in <a href="/wiki/Liberia" title="Liberia">Liberia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFoner201017–19,_67_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFoner201017–19,_67-75">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p>He was <a href="/wiki/Admission_to_the_bar_in_the_United_States" title="Admission to the bar in the United States">admitted</a> to the Illinois bar in 1836,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199664_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199664-76">[70]</a></sup> and moved to Springfield and began to practice law under <a href="/wiki/John_T._Stuart" title="John T. Stuart">John T. Stuart</a>, Mary Todd's cousin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite200971,_79,_108_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite200971,_79,_108-77">[71]</a></sup> Lincoln emerged as a formidable trial combatant during cross-examinations and closing arguments. He partnered several years with <a href="/wiki/Stephen_T._Logan" title="Stephen T. Logan">Stephen T. Logan</a>, and in 1844 began <a href="/wiki/Lincoln-Herndon_Law_Offices_State_Historic_Site" title="Lincoln-Herndon Law Offices State Historic Site">his practice</a> with <a href="/wiki/William_Herndon_(lawyer)" title="William Herndon (lawyer)">William Herndon</a>, "a studious young man".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199617_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199617-78">[72]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="U.S._House_of_Representatives_.281847.E2.80.931849.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="U.S._House_of_Representatives_(1847–1849)">U.S. House of Representatives (1847–1849)</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_by_Nicholas_Shepherd,_1846-crop.jpg"><img alt="Middle aged clean shaven Lincoln from the hips up." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2849" data-file-width="2249" decoding="async" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Abraham_Lincoln_by_Nicholas_Shepherd%2C_1846-crop.jpg/170px-Abraham_Lincoln_by_Nicholas_Shepherd%2C_1846-crop.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Abraham_Lincoln_by_Nicholas_Shepherd%2C_1846-crop.jpg/255px-Abraham_Lincoln_by_Nicholas_Shepherd%2C_1846-crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Abraham_Lincoln_by_Nicholas_Shepherd%2C_1846-crop.jpg/340px-Abraham_Lincoln_by_Nicholas_Shepherd%2C_1846-crop.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_by_Nicholas_Shepherd,_1846-crop.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lincoln in his late 30s as a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="United States House of Representatives">U.S. House of Representatives</a>. Photo taken by one of Lincoln's law students around 1846.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:213px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_in_the_United_States_Congress_by.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="864" data-file-width="650" decoding="async" height="280" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Abraham_Lincoln_in_the_United_States_Congress_by.jpg/211px-Abraham_Lincoln_in_the_United_States_Congress_by.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Abraham_Lincoln_in_the_United_States_Congress_by.jpg/316px-Abraham_Lincoln_in_the_United_States_Congress_by.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Abraham_Lincoln_in_the_United_States_Congress_by.jpg/421px-Abraham_Lincoln_in_the_United_States_Congress_by.jpg 2x" width="211"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_in_the_United_States_Congress_by.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Official Portrait of Lincoln in Congress by <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Ned_Bittinger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Ned Bittinger (page does not exist)">Ned Bittinger</a></div></div></div><p>True to his record, Lincoln professed to friends in 1861 to be "an old line Whig, a disciple of Henry Clay".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996222_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996222-79">[73]</a></sup> Their party favored economic modernization in banking, tariffs to fund <a href="/wiki/Internal_improvements" title="Internal improvements">internal improvements</a> including railroads, and urbanization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBorittPinsker2002137–153_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBorittPinsker2002137–153-80">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1843, Lincoln sought the Whig nomination for <a href="/wiki/Illinois%27s_7th_congressional_district" title="Illinois's 7th congressional district">Illinois' 7th district seat</a> in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="United States House of Representatives">U.S. House of Representatives</a>; he was defeated by <a href="/wiki/John_J._Hardin" title="John J. Hardin">John J. Hardin</a> though he prevailed with the party in limiting Hardin to one term. Lincoln not only pulled off his strategy of gaining the nomination in 1846 but also won the election. He was the only Whig in the Illinois delegation, but as dutiful as any participated in almost all votes and made speeches that toed the party line.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOates197479_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOates197479-81">[75]</a></sup> He was assigned to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_Post_Office_and_Post_Roads" title="United States House Committee on Post Office and Post Roads">Committee on Post Office and Post Roads</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_Expenditures_in_the_War_Department" title="United States House Committee on Expenditures in the War Department">Committee on Expenditures in the War Department</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[76]</a></sup> Lincoln teamed with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joshua_R._Giddings" title="Joshua R. Giddings">Joshua R. Giddings</a> on a bill to abolish slavery in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Washington,_District_of_Columbia" title="Washington, District of Columbia">District of Columbia</a> with compensation for the owners, enforcement to capture fugitive slaves, and a popular vote on the matter. He dropped the bill when it eluded Whig support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris200754Foner201057_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris200754Foner201057-83">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_views">Political views</span></h3>
<p>On foreign and military policy, Lincoln spoke against the <a href="/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War" title="Mexican–American War">Mexican–American War</a>, which he imputed to President <a href="/wiki/James_K._Polk" title="James K. Polk">James K. Polk</a>'s desire for "military glory—that attractive rainbow, that rises in showers of blood".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeidlerHeidler2006181–183_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeidlerHeidler2006181–183-85">[79]</a></sup> He supported the <a href="/wiki/Wilmot_Proviso" title="Wilmot Proviso">Wilmot Proviso</a>, a failed proposal to ban slavery in any U.S. territory won from Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHolzer200463_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHolzer200463-86">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lincoln emphasized his opposition to Polk by drafting and introducing his <a href="/wiki/Spot_Resolutions" title="Spot Resolutions">Spot Resolutions</a>. The war had begun with a Mexican slaughter of American soldiers in territory disputed by Mexico, and Polk insisted that Mexican soldiers had "invaded our territory and shed the blood of our fellow-citizens on our own soil."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOates197479–80_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOates197479–80-87">[81]</a></sup> Lincoln demanded that Polk show Congress the exact spot on which blood had been shed and prove that the spot was on American soil.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGraebner1959199–202_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraebner1959199–202-88">[82]</a></sup> The resolution was ignored in both Congress and the national papers, and it cost Lincoln political support in his district. One Illinois newspaper derisively nicknamed him "spotty Lincoln".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MuellerSchamel_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-MuellerSchamel-89">[83]</a></sup> Lincoln later regretted some of his statements, especially his attack on presidential war-making powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996128_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996128-90">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lincoln had pledged in 1846 to serve only one term in the House. Realizing Clay was unlikely to win the presidency, he supported General <a href="/wiki/Zachary_Taylor" title="Zachary Taylor">Zachary Taylor</a> for the Whig nomination in the <a href="/wiki/1848_United_States_presidential_election" title="1848 United States presidential election">1848 presidential election</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996124–126_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996124–126-91">[85]</a></sup> Taylor won and Lincoln hoped in vain to be appointed Commissioner of the <a href="/wiki/General_Land_Office" title="General Land Office">General Land Office</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996140_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996140-92">[86]</a></sup> The administration offered to appoint him secretary or governor of the <a href="/wiki/Oregon_Territory" title="Oregon Territory">Oregon Territory</a> as consolation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[87]</a></sup> This distant territory was a Democratic stronghold, and acceptance of the post would have disrupted his legal and political career in Illinois, so he declined and resumed his law practice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris200755–57_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris200755–57-94">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Prairie_lawyer">Prairie lawyer</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cases_involving_Abraham_Lincoln" title="List of cases involving Abraham Lincoln">List of cases involving Abraham Lincoln</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_by_Hesler,_1857.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4226" data-file-width="3215" decoding="async" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Abraham_Lincoln_by_Hesler%2C_1857.jpg/170px-Abraham_Lincoln_by_Hesler%2C_1857.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Abraham_Lincoln_by_Hesler%2C_1857.jpg/255px-Abraham_Lincoln_by_Hesler%2C_1857.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Abraham_Lincoln_by_Hesler%2C_1857.jpg/340px-Abraham_Lincoln_by_Hesler%2C_1857.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_by_Hesler,_1857.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lincoln in 1857</div></div></div>
<p>In his Springfield practice, Lincoln handled "every kind of business that could come before a prairie lawyer".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199696_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199696-95">[89]</a></sup> Twice a year he appeared for 10 consecutive weeks in county seats in the Midstate county courts; this continued for 16 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996105–106,_158_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996105–106,_158-96">[90]</a></sup> Lincoln handled transportation cases in the midst of the nation's western expansion, particularly river barge conflicts under the many new railroad bridges. As a riverboat man, Lincoln initially favored those interests, but ultimately represented whoever hired him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996142–143_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996142–143-97">[91]</a></sup> He later represented a bridge company against a riverboat company in <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hurd_v._Rock_Island_Bridge_Company" title="Hurd v. Rock Island Bridge Company">Hurd v. Rock Island Bridge Company</a></i>, a landmark case involving a canal boat that sank after hitting a bridge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[92]</a></sup> In 1849, he received <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln%27s_patent" title="Abraham Lincoln's patent">a patent for a flotation device</a> for the movement of boats in shallow water. The idea was never commercialized, but it made Lincoln the only president to hold a patent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lincoln appeared before the Illinois Supreme Court in 175 cases; he was sole counsel in 51 cases, of which 31 were decided in his favor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERichards2015440_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERichards2015440-100">[94]</a></sup> From 1853 to 1860, one of his largest clients was the <a href="/wiki/Illinois_Central_Railroad" title="Illinois Central Railroad">Illinois Central Railroad</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996155–156,_196–197_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996155–156,_196–197-101">[95]</a></sup> His legal reputation gave rise to the nickname "Honest Abe".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lincoln argued in an 1858 criminal trial, defending <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_%22Duff%22_Armstrong" title='William "Duff" Armstrong'>William "Duff" Armstrong</a>, who was on trial for the murder of James Preston Metzker.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996150–151_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996150–151-103">[97]</a></sup> The case is famous for Lincoln's use of a fact established by <a href="/wiki/Judicial_notice" title="Judicial notice">judicial notice</a> to challenge the credibility of an eyewitness. After an opposing witness testified to seeing the crime in the moonlight, Lincoln produced a <i><a href="/wiki/Farmers%27_Almanac" title="Farmers' Almanac">Farmers' Almanac</a></i> showing the moon was at a low angle, drastically reducing visibility. Armstrong was acquitted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996150–151_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996150–151-103">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>Leading up to his presidential campaign, Lincoln elevated his profile in an 1859 murder case, with his defense of Simeon Quinn "Peachy" Harrison who was a third cousin;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[g]</a></sup> Harrison was also the grandson of Lincoln's political opponent, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Cartwright_(revivalist)" title="Peter Cartwright (revivalist)">Rev. Peter Cartwright</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarrison1935_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarrison1935-106">[99]</a></sup> Harrison was charged with the murder of Greek Crafton who, as he lay dying of his wounds, confessed to Cartwright that he had provoked Harrison.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[100]</a></sup> Lincoln angrily protested the judge's initial decision to exclude Cartwright's testimony about the confession as inadmissible <a href="/wiki/Hearsay" title="Hearsay">hearsay</a>. Lincoln argued that the testimony involved a <a href="/wiki/Dying_declaration" title="Dying declaration">dying declaration</a> and was not subject to the hearsay rule. Instead of holding Lincoln in contempt of court as expected, the judge, a Democrat, reversed his ruling and admitted the testimony into evidence, resulting in Harrison's acquittal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996150–151_103-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996150–151-103">[97]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Republican_politics_.281854.E2.80.931860.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Republican_politics_(1854–1860)">Republican politics (1854–1860)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln_in_politics,_1849%E2%80%931861" title="Abraham Lincoln in politics, 1849–1861">Abraham Lincoln in politics, 1849–1861</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Emergence_as_Republican_leader">Emergence as Republican leader</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Slave_states_and_free_states" title="Slave states and free states">Slave states and free states</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln_and_slavery" title="Abraham Lincoln and slavery">Abraham Lincoln and slavery</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_by_Byers,_1858_-_crop.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1230" data-file-width="931" decoding="async" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Abraham_Lincoln_by_Byers%2C_1858_-_crop.jpg/170px-Abraham_Lincoln_by_Byers%2C_1858_-_crop.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Abraham_Lincoln_by_Byers%2C_1858_-_crop.jpg/255px-Abraham_Lincoln_by_Byers%2C_1858_-_crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Abraham_Lincoln_by_Byers%2C_1858_-_crop.jpg/340px-Abraham_Lincoln_by_Byers%2C_1858_-_crop.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_by_Byers,_1858_-_crop.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lincoln in 1858, the year of <a href="/wiki/Lincoln%E2%80%93Douglas_debates" title="Lincoln–Douglas debates">his debates</a> with <a href="/wiki/Stephen_A._Douglas" title="Stephen A. Douglas">Stephen Douglas</a> over slavery</div></div></div>
<p>The debate over the status of slavery in the territories failed to alleviate tensions between the slave-holding South and the free North, with the failure of the <a href="/wiki/Compromise_of_1850" title="Compromise of 1850">Compromise of 1850</a>, a legislative package designed to address the issue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009175–176_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009175–176-108">[101]</a></sup> In his 1852 eulogy for Clay, Lincoln highlighted the latter's support for gradual emancipation and opposition to "both extremes" on the slavery issue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009182–185_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009182–185-109">[102]</a></sup> As the slavery debate in the <a href="/wiki/Nebraska_Territory" title="Nebraska Territory">Nebraska</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kansas_Territory" title="Kansas Territory">Kansas</a> territories became particularly acrimonious, Illinois Senator Stephen A. Douglas proposed <a href='/wiki/Popular_sovereignty_in_the_United_States#Emergence_of_the_term_"popular_sovereignty"_and_its_pejorative_connotation' title="Popular sovereignty in the United States">popular sovereignty</a> as a compromise; the measure would allow the electorate of each territory to decide the status of slavery. The legislation alarmed many Northerners, who sought to prevent the spread of slavery that could result, but Douglas's <a href="/wiki/Kansas%E2%80%93Nebraska_Act" title="Kansas–Nebraska Act">Kansas–Nebraska Act</a> narrowly passed Congress in May 1854.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009188–190_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009188–190-110">[103]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lincoln did not comment on the act until months later in his "<a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln%27s_Peoria_speech" title="Abraham Lincoln's Peoria speech">Peoria Speech</a>" of October 1854. Lincoln then declared his opposition to slavery, which he repeated en route to the presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThomas2008148–152_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas2008148–152-111">[104]</a></sup> He said the Kansas Act had a "<i>declared</i> indifference, but as I must think, a covert <i>real</i> zeal for the spread of slavery. I cannot but hate it. I hate it because of the monstrous injustice of slavery itself. I hate it because it deprives our republican example of its just influence in the world ..."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGraebner1959255_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraebner1959255-112">[105]</a></sup> Lincoln's attacks on the Kansas–Nebraska Act marked his return to political life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009203–205_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009203–205-113">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nationally, the Whigs were irreparably split by the Kansas–Nebraska Act and other efforts to compromise on the slavery issue. Reflecting on the demise of his party, Lincoln wrote in 1855, "I think I am a Whig, but others say there are no Whigs, and that I am an abolitionist.... I do no more than oppose the <i>extension</i> of slavery."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009215–216_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009215–216-114">[107]</a></sup> The new <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican Party</a> was formed as a northern party dedicated to antislavery, drawing from the antislavery wing of the Whig Party and combining <a href="/wiki/Free_Soil_Party" title="Free Soil Party">Free Soil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Party_(United_States,_1840)" title="Liberty Party (United States, 1840)">Liberty</a>, and antislavery <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic Party</a> members,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcGovern200938–39_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcGovern200938–39-115">[108]</a></sup> Lincoln resisted early Republican entreaties, fearing that the new party would become a platform for extreme abolitionists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009203–204_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009203–204-116">[109]</a></sup> Lincoln held out hope for rejuvenating the Whigs, though he lamented his party's growing closeness with the nativist <a href="/wiki/Know_Nothing" title="Know Nothing">Know Nothing</a> movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009191–194_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009191–194-117">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1854, Lincoln was elected to the Illinois legislature but declined to take his seat. The year's elections showed the strong opposition to the Kansas–Nebraska Act, and in the aftermath, Lincoln sought election to the United States Senate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009203–205_113-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009203–205-113">[106]</a></sup> At that time, senators were elected by the state legislature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOates1974119_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOates1974119-118">[111]</a></sup> After leading in the first six rounds of voting, he was unable to obtain a majority. Lincoln instructed his backers to vote for <a href="/wiki/Lyman_Trumbull" title="Lyman Trumbull">Lyman Trumbull</a>. Trumbull was an antislavery Democrat, and had received few votes in the earlier ballots; his supporters, also antislavery Democrats, had vowed not to support any Whig. Lincoln's decision to withdraw enabled his Whig supporters and Trumbull's antislavery Democrats to combine and defeat the mainstream Democratic candidate, <a href="/wiki/Joel_Aldrich_Matteson" title="Joel Aldrich Matteson">Joel Aldrich Matteson</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009205–208_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009205–208-119">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="1856_campaign">1856 campaign</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Bleeding_Kansas" title="Bleeding Kansas">Violent political confrontations in Kansas</a> continued, and opposition to the Kansas–Nebraska Act remained strong throughout the North. As the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_elections,_1856" title="United States elections, 1856">1856 elections</a> approached, Lincoln joined the Republicans and attended the <a href="/wiki/Bloomington_Convention" title="Bloomington Convention">Bloomington Convention</a>, which formally established the <a href="/wiki/Illinois_Republican_Party" title="Illinois Republican Party">Illinois Republican Party</a>. The convention platform endorsed Congress's right to regulate slavery in the territories and backed the admission of Kansas as a free state. Lincoln gave the <a href="/wiki/Lincoln%27s_Lost_Speech" title="Lincoln's Lost Speech">final speech</a> of the convention supporting the party platform and called for the preservation of the Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009216–221_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009216–221-120">[113]</a></sup> At the June <a href="/wiki/1856_Republican_National_Convention" title="1856 Republican National Convention">1856 Republican National Convention</a>, though Lincoln received support to run as vice president, <a href="/wiki/John_C._Fr%C3%A9mont" title="John C. Frémont">John C. Frémont</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_Dayton" title="William Dayton">William Dayton</a> comprised the ticket, which Lincoln supported throughout Illinois. The Democrats nominated former Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/James_Buchanan" title="James Buchanan">James Buchanan</a> and the Know-Nothings nominated former Whig President <a href="/wiki/Millard_Fillmore" title="Millard Fillmore">Millard Fillmore</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009224–228_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009224–228-121">[114]</a></sup> Buchanan prevailed, while Republican <a href="/wiki/William_Henry_Bissell" title="William Henry Bissell">William Henry Bissell</a> won election as Governor of Illinois, and Lincoln became a leading Republican in Illinois.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009229–230_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009229–230-122">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[h]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oil_on_Canvas_Portrait_of_Dred_Scott_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="Painting" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4321" data-file-width="3495" decoding="async" height="272" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Oil_on_Canvas_Portrait_of_Dred_Scott_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Oil_on_Canvas_Portrait_of_Dred_Scott_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Oil_on_Canvas_Portrait_of_Dred_Scott_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Oil_on_Canvas_Portrait_of_Dred_Scott_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Oil_on_Canvas_Portrait_of_Dred_Scott_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Oil_on_Canvas_Portrait_of_Dred_Scott_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oil_on_Canvas_Portrait_of_Dred_Scott_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A portrait of <a href="/wiki/Dred_Scott" title="Dred Scott">Dred Scott</a>, petitioner in <i><a href="/wiki/Dred_Scott_v._Sandford" title="Dred Scott v. Sandford">Dred Scott v. Sandford</a></i></div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Dred_Scott_v._Sandford"><i>Dred Scott v. Sandford</i></span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Dred_Scott" title="Dred Scott">Dred Scott</a> was a slave whose master took him from a slave state to a territory that was free as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Missouri_Compromise" title="Missouri Compromise">Missouri Compromise</a>. After Scott was returned to the slave state he petitioned a federal court for his freedom. His petition was denied in <i><a href="/wiki/Dred_Scott_v._Sandford" title="Dred Scott v. Sandford">Dred Scott v. Sandford</a></i> (1857).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[i]</a></sup> In his opinion, Supreme Court Chief Justice <a href="/wiki/Roger_B._Taney" title="Roger B. Taney">Roger B. Taney</a> wrote that black people were not citizens and derived no rights from the Constitution, and that the Missouri Compromise was unconstitutional for infringing upon slave owners' "property" rights. While many Democrats hoped that <i>Dred Scott</i> would end the dispute over slavery in the territories, the decision sparked further outrage in the North.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009236–238_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009236–238-127">[118]</a></sup> Lincoln denounced it as the product of a conspiracy of Democrats to support the <a href="/wiki/Slave_Power" title="Slave Power">Slave Power</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZarefsky199369–110_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZarefsky199369–110-128">[119]</a></sup> He argued the decision was at variance with the Declaration of Independence; he said that while the founding fathers did not believe all men equal in every respect, they believed all men were equal "in certain inalienable rights, among which are life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJaffa2000299–300_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJaffa2000299–300-129">[120]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Lincoln.E2.80.93Douglas_debates_and_Cooper_Union_speech"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Lincoln–Douglas_debates_and_Cooper_Union_speech">Lincoln–Douglas debates and Cooper Union speech</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Lincoln%E2%80%93Douglas_debates" title="Lincoln–Douglas debates">Lincoln–Douglas debates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cooper_Union_speech" title="Cooper Union speech">Cooper Union speech</a></div>
<p>In 1858, Douglas was up for re-election in the U.S. Senate, and Lincoln hoped to defeat him. Many in the party felt that a former Whig should be nominated in 1858, and Lincoln's 1856 campaigning and support of Trumbull had earned him a favor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009247–248_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009247–248-130">[121]</a></sup> Some eastern Republicans supported Douglas for his opposition to the <a href="/wiki/Lecompton_Constitution" title="Lecompton Constitution">Lecompton Constitution</a> and admission of Kansas as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slave_state" title="Slave state">slave state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOates1974138–139_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOates1974138–139-131">[122]</a></sup> Many Illinois Republicans resented this eastern interference. For the first time, Illinois Republicans held a convention to agree upon a Senate candidate, and Lincoln won the nomination with little opposition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009247–250_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009247–250-132">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_O-17_by_Brady,_1860.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1011" data-file-width="630" decoding="async" height="353" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Lincoln_O-17_by_Brady%2C_1860.png/220px-Lincoln_O-17_by_Brady%2C_1860.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Lincoln_O-17_by_Brady%2C_1860.png/330px-Lincoln_O-17_by_Brady%2C_1860.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Lincoln_O-17_by_Brady%2C_1860.png/440px-Lincoln_O-17_by_Brady%2C_1860.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_O-17_by_Brady,_1860.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Abraham Lincoln</i>, a portrait by <a href="/wiki/Mathew_Brady" title="Mathew Brady">Mathew Brady</a> taken February 27, 1860, the day of Lincoln's <a href="/wiki/Cooper_Union_speech" title="Cooper Union speech">Cooper Union speech</a></div></div></div>
<p>Lincoln accepted the nomination with great enthusiasm and zeal. After his nomination he delivered his <a href="/wiki/Lincoln%27s_House_Divided_Speech" title="Lincoln's House Divided Speech">House Divided Speech</a>, with the biblical reference <a href="/wiki/Mark_3" title="Mark 3">Mark 3</a>:25, "A house divided against itself cannot stand. I believe this government cannot endure permanently half slave and half free. I do not expect the Union to be dissolved—I do not expect the house to fall—but I do expect it will cease to be divided. It will become all one thing, or all the other."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009251_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009251-133">[124]</a></sup> The speech created a stark image of the danger of disunion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris200798_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris200798-134">[125]</a></sup> The stage was then set for the election of the Illinois legislature which would, in turn, select Lincoln or Douglas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996209_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996209-135">[126]</a></sup> When informed of Lincoln's nomination, Douglas stated, "[Lincoln] is the strong man of the party ... and if I beat him, my victory will be hardly won."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009257–258_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009257–258-136">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Senate campaign featured seven <a href="/wiki/Lincoln%E2%80%93Douglas_debates" title="Lincoln–Douglas debates">debates</a> between Lincoln and Douglas.
