These were the most famous political debates in American history; they had an atmosphere akin to a prizefight and drew crowds in the thousands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996214–218_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996214–218-137">[128]</a></sup> The principals stood in stark contrast both physically and politically. Lincoln warned that Douglas' "Slave Power" was threatening the values of republicanism, and accused Douglas of distorting the Founding Fathers' premise that <a href="/wiki/All_men_are_created_equal" title="All men are created equal">all men are created equal</a>. Douglas emphasized his <a href="/wiki/Freeport_Doctrine" title="Freeport Doctrine">Freeport Doctrine</a>, that local settlers were free to choose whether to allow slavery and accused Lincoln of having joined the abolitionists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996214–224_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996214–224-138">[129]</a></sup> Lincoln's argument assumed a moral tone, as he claimed Douglas represented a conspiracy to promote slavery. Douglas's argument was more legal, claiming that Lincoln was defying the authority of the U.S. Supreme Court in the <i>Dred Scott</i> decision.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996223_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996223-139">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>Though the Republican legislative candidates won more popular votes, the Democrats won more seats, and the legislature re-elected Douglas. Lincoln's articulation of the issues gave him a national political presence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarwardine200389–90_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarwardine200389–90-140">[131]</a></sup> In May 1859, Lincoln purchased the <i>Illinois Staats-Anzeiger</i>, a German-language newspaper that was consistently supportive; most of the state's 130,000 German Americans voted Democratically but the German-language paper mobilized Republican support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996242,_412_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996242,_412-141">[132]</a></sup> In the aftermath of the 1858 election, newspapers frequently mentioned Lincoln as a potential Republican presidential candidate, rivaled by <a href="/wiki/William_H._Seward" title="William H. Seward">William H. Seward</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salmon_P._Chase" title="Salmon P. Chase">Salmon P. Chase</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edward_Bates" title="Edward Bates">Edward Bates</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Simon_Cameron" title="Simon Cameron">Simon Cameron</a>. While Lincoln was popular in the Midwest, he lacked support in the Northeast and was unsure whether to seek office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009291–293_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009291–293-142">[133]</a></sup> In January 1860, Lincoln told a group of political allies that he would accept the nomination if offered, and in the following months' several local papers endorsed his candidacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009307–308_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009307–308-143">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over the coming months, Lincoln was tireless, making nearly fifty speeches along the campaign trail. By the quality and simplicity of his rhetoric, he quickly became the champion of the Republican party. However, despite his overwhelming support in the <a href="/wiki/Midwestern_United_States" title="Midwestern United States">Midwestern United States</a>, he was less appreciated in the east. <a href="/wiki/Horace_Greeley" title="Horace Greeley">Horace Greeley</a>, editor of the New York Tribune, at that time wrote up an unflattering account of Lincoln's compromising position on slavery and his reluctance to challenge the court's Dred-Scott ruling, which was promptly used against him by his political rivals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996200_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996200-144">[135]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorse1893112_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorse1893112-145">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>On February 27, 1860, powerful New York Republicans invited Lincoln to give a <a href="/wiki/Cooper_Union_speech" title="Cooper Union speech">speech at Cooper Union</a>, in which he argued that the <a href="/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States" title="Founding Fathers of the United States">Founding Fathers of the United States</a> had little use for popular sovereignty and had repeatedly sought to restrict slavery. He insisted that morality required opposition to slavery, and rejected any "groping for some middle ground between the right and the wrong".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJaffa2000473_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJaffa2000473-146">[137]</a></sup> Many in the audience thought he appeared awkward and even ugly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHolzer2004108–111_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHolzer2004108–111-147">[138]</a></sup> But Lincoln demonstrated intellectual leadership that brought him into contention. Journalist <a href="/wiki/Noah_Brooks" title="Noah Brooks">Noah Brooks</a> reported, "No man ever before made such an impression on his first appeal to a New York audience."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarwardine200397Holzer2004157_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarwardine200397Holzer2004157-148">[139]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historian <a href="/wiki/David_Herbert_Donald" title="David Herbert Donald">David Herbert Donald</a> described the speech as "a superb political move for an unannounced presidential aspirant. Appearing in Seward's home state, sponsored by a group largely loyal to Chase, Lincoln shrewdly made no reference to either of these Republican rivals for the nomination".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996240_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996240-149">[140]</a></sup> In response to an inquiry about his ambitions, Lincoln said, "The taste <i>is</i> in my mouth a little."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996241_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996241-150">[141]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1860_presidential_election">1860 presidential election</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/1860_United_States_presidential_election" title="1860 United States presidential election">1860 United States presidential election</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AbrLincoln1860ColeT.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="562" data-file-width="450" decoding="async" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/AbrLincoln1860ColeT.jpg/170px-AbrLincoln1860ColeT.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/AbrLincoln1860ColeT.jpg/255px-AbrLincoln1860ColeT.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/AbrLincoln1860ColeT.jpg/340px-AbrLincoln1860ColeT.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:AbrLincoln1860ColeT.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Timothy_Cole" title="Timothy Cole">Timothy Cole</a> wood engraving taken from a May 20, 1860, ambrotype of Lincoln, two days following his nomination for president</div></div></div>
<p>On May 9–10, 1860, the Illinois Republican State Convention was held in Decatur.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996244_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996244-151">[142]</a></sup> Lincoln's followers organized a campaign team led by <a href="/wiki/David_Davis_(Supreme_Court_justice)" title="David Davis (Supreme Court justice)">David Davis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Norman_B._Judd" title="Norman B. Judd">Norman Judd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonard_Swett" title="Leonard Swett">Leonard Swett</a>, and Jesse DuBois, and Lincoln received his first endorsement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOates1974175–176_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOates1974175–176-152">[143]</a></sup> Exploiting his embellished frontier legend (clearing land and splitting fence rails), Lincoln's supporters adopted the label of "The Rail Candidate".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996245_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996245-153">[144]</a></sup> In 1860, Lincoln described himself: "I am in height, six feet, four inches, nearly; lean in flesh, weighing, on an average, one hundred and eighty pounds; dark complexion, with coarse black hair, and gray eyes."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[145]</a></sup> Michael Martinez wrote about the effective imaging of Lincoln by his campaign. At times he was presented as the plain-talking "Rail Splitter" and at other times he was "Honest Abe", unpolished but trustworthy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[146]</a></sup>
</p><p>On May 18, at the <a href="/wiki/1860_Republican_National_Convention" title="1860 Republican National Convention">Republican National Convention</a> in Chicago, Lincoln won the nomination on the third ballot, beating candidates such as Seward and Chase. A former Democrat, <a href="/wiki/Hannibal_Hamlin" title="Hannibal Hamlin">Hannibal Hamlin</a> of Maine, was nominated for vice president to <a href="/wiki/Ticket_balance" title="Ticket balance">balance the ticket</a>. Lincoln's success depended on his campaign team, his reputation as a moderate on the slavery issue, and his strong support for internal improvements and the tariff.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELuthin1944609–629_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELuthin1944609–629-156">[147]</a></sup>
Pennsylvania put him over the top, led by the state's iron interests who were reassured by his tariff support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHofstadter193850–55_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHofstadter193850–55-157">[148]</a></sup> Lincoln's managers had focused on this delegation while honoring Lincoln's dictate to "Make no contracts that will bind me".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996247–250_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996247–250-158">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>As the Slave Power tightened its grip on the national government, most Republicans agreed with Lincoln that the North was the aggrieved party. Throughout the 1850s, Lincoln had doubted the prospects of civil war, and his supporters rejected claims that his election would incite secession.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBorittPinsker200210,_13,_18_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBorittPinsker200210,_13,_18-159">[150]</a></sup> When Douglas was selected as the candidate of the Northern Democrats, delegates from eleven slave states walked out of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1860_Democratic_National_Convention" title="1860 Democratic National Convention">Democratic convention</a>; they opposed Douglas's position on popular sovereignty, and selected incumbent Vice President <a href="/wiki/John_C._Breckinridge" title="John C. Breckinridge">John C. Breckinridge</a> as their candidate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996253_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996253-160">[151]</a></sup> A group of former Whigs and Know Nothings formed the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Union_Party_(United_States)" title="Constitutional Union Party (United States)">Constitutional Union Party</a> and nominated <a href="/wiki/John_Bell_(Tennessee_politician)" title="John Bell (Tennessee politician)">John Bell</a> of Tennessee. Lincoln and Douglas competed for votes in the North, while Bell and Breckinridge primarily found support in the South.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009247–248_130-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009247–248-130">[121]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:492px;max-width:492px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:213px;max-width:213px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:158px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Rail_Candidate.jpg"><img alt="Lincoln being carried by two men on a long board." data-file-height="3544" data-file-width="4720" decoding="async" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/The_Rail_Candidate.jpg/211px-The_Rail_Candidate.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/The_Rail_Candidate.jpg/317px-The_Rail_Candidate.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/The_Rail_Candidate.jpg/422px-The_Rail_Candidate.jpg 2x" width="211"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><i>The Rail Candidate</i>—Lincoln's 1860 platform, portrayed as being held up by a slave and his party</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:275px;max-width:275px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:158px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege1860.svg"><img alt="Map of the U.S. showing Lincoln winning the North-east and West, Breckinridge winning the South, Douglas winning Missouri, and Bell winning Virginia, West Virginia, and Kentucky." data-file-height="593" data-file-width="1020" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/ElectoralCollege1860.svg/273px-ElectoralCollege1860.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/ElectoralCollege1860.svg/410px-ElectoralCollege1860.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/ElectoralCollege1860.svg/546px-ElectoralCollege1860.svg.png 2x" width="273"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">In 1860, northern and western <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electoral_College_(United_States)" title="Electoral College (United States)">electoral</a> votes (shown in red) put Lincoln into the White House.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Prior to the Republican convention, the Lincoln campaign began cultivating a nationwide youth organization, the <a href="/wiki/Wide_Awakes" title="Wide Awakes">Wide Awakes</a>, which it used to generate popular support throughout the country to spearhead voter registration drives, thinking that new voters and young voters tended to embrace new parties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Audacious_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-Audacious-161">[152]</a></sup> People of the Northern states knew the Southern states would vote against Lincoln and rallied supporters for Lincoln.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-murrin_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-murrin-162">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>As Douglas and the other candidates campaigned, Lincoln gave no speeches, relying on the enthusiasm of the Republican Party. The party did the leg work that produced majorities across the North and produced an abundance of campaign posters, leaflets, and newspaper editorials. Republican speakers focused first on the party platform, and second on Lincoln's life story, emphasizing his childhood poverty. The goal was to demonstrate the power of "free labor", which allowed a common farm boy to work his way to the top by his own efforts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996254–256_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996254–256-163">[154]</a></sup> The Republican Party's production of campaign literature dwarfed the combined opposition; a <i>Chicago Tribune</i> writer produced a pamphlet that detailed Lincoln's life and sold 100,000–200,000 copies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996254_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996254-164">[155]</a></sup> Though he did not give public appearances, many sought to visit him and write him. In the runup to the election, he took an office in the Illinois state capitol to deal with the influx of attention. He also hired <a href="/wiki/John_George_Nicolay" title="John George Nicolay">John George Nicolay</a> as his personal secretary, who would remain in that role during the presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996251–252_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996251–252-165">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>On November 6, 1860, Lincoln was elected the 16th president. He was the first Republican president and his victory was entirely due to his support in the North and West. No ballots were cast for him in 10 of the 15 Southern slave states, and he won only two of 996 counties in all the Southern states, an omen of the impending Civil War.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMansch200561_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMansch200561-166">[157]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996256_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996256-167">[158]</a></sup> Lincoln received 1,866,452 votes, or 39.8% of the total in a four-way race, carrying the free Northern states, as well as California and Oregon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009350_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009350-168">[159]</a></sup> His victory in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College" title="United States Electoral College">electoral college</a> was decisive: Lincoln had 180 votes to 123 for his opponents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENevins19474:312_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENevins19474:312-169">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Presidency_.281861.E2.80.931865.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Presidency_(1861–1865)">Presidency (1861–1865)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Presidency of Abraham Lincoln">Presidency of Abraham Lincoln</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Secession_and_inauguration">Secession and inauguration</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_1861.jpg"><img alt="A large crowd in front of a large building with many pillars." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3805" data-file-width="3795" decoding="async" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_1861.jpg/220px-Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_1861.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_1861.jpg/330px-Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_1861.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_1861.jpg/440px-Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_1861.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_1861.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln%27s_first_inaugural_address" title="Abraham Lincoln's first inaugural address">Lincoln's first inaugural</a> at the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Capitol" title="United States Capitol">United States Capitol</a>, March 4, 1861. <a href="/wiki/United_States_Capitol_dome" title="United States Capitol dome">The Capitol dome</a> above the rotunda was still under construction.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:18610304_Affairs_of_the_Nation_-_Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_-_The_New_York_Times.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1550" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/18610304_Affairs_of_the_Nation_-_Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_-_The_New_York_Times.jpg/330px-18610304_Affairs_of_the_Nation_-_Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_-_The_New_York_Times.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/18610304_Affairs_of_the_Nation_-_Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_-_The_New_York_Times.jpg/495px-18610304_Affairs_of_the_Nation_-_Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_-_The_New_York_Times.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/18610304_Affairs_of_the_Nation_-_Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_-_The_New_York_Times.jpg/660px-18610304_Affairs_of_the_Nation_-_Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_-_The_New_York_Times.jpg 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:18610304_Affairs_of_the_Nation_-_Abraham_Lincoln_inauguration_-_The_New_York_Times.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">New York Times</a></i> headlines covering Lincoln's first inauguration on March 4, 1861. Less than six weeks later, on April 12, the South attacked <a href="/wiki/Fort_Sumter" title="Fort Sumter">Fort Sumter</a>, launching the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes_18610304_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes_18610304-170">[161]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Presidential_transition_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Presidential transition of Abraham Lincoln">Presidential transition of Abraham Lincoln</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secession_winter" title="Secession winter">Secession winter</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Plot" title="Baltimore Plot">Baltimore Plot</a></div>
<p>The South was outraged by Lincoln's election, and in response secessionists implemented plans to leave the Union before he took office in March 1861.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEdgar1998350_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEdgar1998350-171">[162]</a></sup> On December 20, 1860, South Carolina took the lead by adopting an ordinance of secession; by February 1, 1861, Florida, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, and Texas followed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996267Potter1977_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996267Potter1977-172">[163]</a></sup> Six of these states declared themselves to be a sovereign nation, the <a href="/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America" title="Confederate States of America">Confederate States of America</a>, and adopted a constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996267_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996267-173">[164]</a></sup> The upper South and border states (Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, Tennessee, Kentucky, Missouri, and Arkansas) initially rejected the secessionist appeal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009362_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009362-174">[165]</a></sup> President Buchanan and President-elect Lincoln refused to recognize the Confederacy, declaring secession illegal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPotter1977520,_569–570_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPotter1977520,_569–570-175">[166]</a></sup> The Confederacy selected <a href="/wiki/Jefferson_Davis" title="Jefferson Davis">Jefferson Davis</a> as its provisional president on February 9, 1861.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009369_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009369-176">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>Attempts at compromise followed but Lincoln and the Republicans rejected the proposed <a href="/wiki/Crittenden_Compromise" title="Crittenden Compromise">Crittenden Compromise</a> as contrary to the Party's platform of free-soil in the <a href="/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States" title="Territories of the United States">territories</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009360–361_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009360–361-177">[168]</a></sup> Lincoln said, "I will suffer death before I consent ... to any concession or compromise which looks like buying the privilege to take possession of this government to which we have a constitutional right."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996268_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996268-178">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lincoln tacitly supported the <a href="/wiki/Corwin_Amendment" title="Corwin Amendment">Corwin Amendment</a> to the Constitution, which passed Congress and was awaiting ratification by the states when Lincoln took office. That doomed amendment would have protected slavery in states where it already existed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVorenberg200122Vile2003280–281_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVorenberg200122Vile2003280–281-179">[170]</a></sup> A few weeks before the war, Lincoln sent a letter to every governor informing them Congress had passed a joint resolution to amend the Constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELupton200634_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELupton200634-180">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p>En route to his inauguration, Lincoln addressed crowds and legislatures across the North.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996273–277_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996273–277-181">[172]</a></sup> He gave a particularly emotional <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln%27s_farewell_address" title="Abraham Lincoln's farewell address">farewell address</a> upon leaving Springfield; he would never again return to Springfield alive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-182">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[174]</a></sup> The president-elect evaded suspected <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Plot" title="Baltimore Plot">assassins in Baltimore</a>. On February 23, 1861, he arrived in disguise in Washington, D.C., which was placed under substantial military guard.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996277–279_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996277–279-184">[175]</a></sup> Lincoln directed <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln%27s_first_inaugural_address" title="Abraham Lincoln's first inaugural address">his inaugural address</a> to the South, proclaiming once again that he had no inclination to abolish slavery in the Southern states:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Apprehension seems to exist among the people of the Southern States, that by the accession of a Republican Administration, their property, and their peace, and personal security, are to be endangered. There has never been any reasonable cause for such apprehension. Indeed, the most ample evidence to the contrary has all the while existed, and been open to their inspection. It is found in nearly all the published speeches of him who now addresses you. I do but quote from one of those speeches when I declare that "I have no purpose, directly or indirectly, to interfere with the institution of slavery in the States where it exists. I believe I have no lawful right to do so, and I have no inclination to do so."</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite><a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln%27s_first_inaugural_address" title="Abraham Lincoln's first inaugural address">First inaugural address</a>, 4 March 1861<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[176]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandburg2002212_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandburg2002212-186">[177]</a></sup></cite></div></blockquote><p> Lincoln cited his plans for banning the expansion of slavery as the key source of conflict between North and South, stating "One section of our country believes slavery is right and ought to be extended, while the other believes it is wrong and ought not to be extended. This is the only substantial dispute." The president ended his address with an appeal to the people of the South: "We are not enemies, but friends. We must not be enemies.... The mystic chords of memory, stretching from every battlefield, and patriot grave, to every living heart and hearthstone, all over this broad land, will yet swell the chorus of the Union, when again touched, as surely they will be, by the better angels of our nature."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996283–284_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996283–284-187">[178]</a></sup> The failure of the <a href="/wiki/Peace_Conference_of_1861" title="Peace Conference of 1861">Peace Conference of 1861</a> signaled that legislative compromise was impossible. By March 1861, no leaders of the insurrection had proposed rejoining the Union on any terms. Meanwhile, Lincoln and the Republican leadership agreed that the dismantling of the Union could not be tolerated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996268,_279_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996268,_279-188">[179]</a></sup> In his <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lincoln%27s_second_inaugural_address" title="Lincoln's second inaugural address">second inaugural address</a>, Lincoln looked back on the situation at the time and said: "Both parties deprecated war, but one of them would make war rather than let the Nation survive, and the other would accept war rather than let it perish, and the war came."
</p><h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_War">Civil War</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Sumter" title="Battle of Fort Sumter">Battle of Fort Sumter</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_O-55,_1861-crop.jpg"><img alt="President Abraham Lincoln in 1861" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1036" data-file-width="829" decoding="async" height="275" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Abraham_Lincoln_O-55%2C_1861-crop.jpg/220px-Abraham_Lincoln_O-55%2C_1861-crop.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Abraham_Lincoln_O-55%2C_1861-crop.jpg/330px-Abraham_Lincoln_O-55%2C_1861-crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Abraham_Lincoln_O-55%2C_1861-crop.jpg/440px-Abraham_Lincoln_O-55%2C_1861-crop.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_O-55,_1861-crop.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President Lincoln in 1861</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Maryland,_Antietam,_President_Lincoln_on_the_Battlefield_-_NARA_-_533297.jpg"><img alt="Lincoln among a group of soldiers in a military camp" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2187" data-file-width="2883" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Maryland%2C_Antietam%2C_President_Lincoln_on_the_Battlefield_-_NARA_-_533297.jpg/220px-Maryland%2C_Antietam%2C_President_Lincoln_on_the_Battlefield_-_NARA_-_533297.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Maryland%2C_Antietam%2C_President_Lincoln_on_the_Battlefield_-_NARA_-_533297.jpg/330px-Maryland%2C_Antietam%2C_President_Lincoln_on_the_Battlefield_-_NARA_-_533297.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Maryland%2C_Antietam%2C_President_Lincoln_on_the_Battlefield_-_NARA_-_533297.jpg/440px-Maryland%2C_Antietam%2C_President_Lincoln_on_the_Battlefield_-_NARA_-_533297.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Maryland,_Antietam,_President_Lincoln_on_the_Battlefield_-_NARA_-_533297.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lincoln with officers after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Antietam" title="Battle of Antietam">Battle of Antietam</a>. Notable figures (from left) are 1. Col. <a href="/wiki/Delos_Bennett_Sackett" title="Delos Bennett Sackett">Delos Sackett</a>; 4. Gen. <a href="/wiki/George_W._Morell" title="George W. Morell">George W. Morell</a>; 5. <a href="/wiki/Alexander_S._Webb" title="Alexander S. Webb">Alexander S. Webb</a>, Chief of Staff, V Corps; 6. McClellan;. 8. Dr. <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Letterman" title="Jonathan Letterman">Jonathan Letterman</a>; 10. Lincoln; 11. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Henry_J._Hunt" title="Henry J. Hunt">Henry J. Hunt</a>; 12. <a href="/wiki/Fitz_John_Porter" title="Fitz John Porter">Fitz John Porter</a>; 15. <a href="/wiki/Andrew_A._Humphreys" title="Andrew A. Humphreys">Andrew A. Humphreys</a>; 16. Capt. <a href="/wiki/George_Armstrong_Custer" title="George Armstrong Custer">George Armstrong Custer</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Robert_Anderson_(Civil_War)" title="Robert Anderson (Civil War)">Major Robert Anderson</a>, commander of the Union's <a href="/wiki/Fort_Sumter" title="Fort Sumter">Fort Sumter</a> in Charleston, South Carolina, sent a request for provisions to Washington, and Lincoln's order to meet that request was seen by the secessionists as an act of war. On April 12, 1861, Confederate forces fired on Union troops <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Sumter" title="Battle of Fort Sumter">at Fort Sumter</a> and began the fight. Historian <a href="/wiki/Allan_Nevins" title="Allan Nevins">Allan Nevins</a> argued that the newly inaugurated Lincoln made three miscalculations: underestimating the gravity of the crisis, exaggerating the strength of Unionist sentiment in the South, and overlooking <a href="/wiki/Southern_Unionist" title="Southern Unionist">Southern Unionist</a> opposition to an invasion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENevins19595:29_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENevins19595:29-189">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/William_Tecumseh_Sherman" title="William Tecumseh Sherman">William Tecumseh Sherman</a> talked to Lincoln during inauguration week and was "sadly disappointed" at his failure to realize that "the country was sleeping on a volcano" and that the South was preparing for war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESherman1990185–186_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESherman1990185–186-190">[181]</a></sup> Donald concludes that, "His repeated efforts to avoid collision in the months between inauguration and the firing on Ft. Sumter showed he adhered to his vow not to be the first to shed fraternal blood. But he also vowed not to surrender the forts. The only resolution of these contradictory positions was for the confederates to fire the first shot; they did just that."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996293_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996293-191">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>On April 15, Lincoln called on the states to send a total of <a href="/wiki/President_Lincoln%27s_75,000_volunteers" title="President Lincoln's 75,000 volunteers">75,000 volunteer troops</a> to recapture forts, protect Washington, and "preserve the Union", which, in his view, remained intact despite the seceding states. This call forced states to choose sides. Virginia seceded and was rewarded with the designation of <a href="/wiki/Richmond,_Virginia" title="Richmond, Virginia">Richmond</a> as the Confederate capital, despite its exposure to Union lines. North Carolina, Tennessee, and Arkansas followed over the following two months. Secession sentiment was strong in Missouri and Maryland, but did not prevail; Kentucky remained neutral.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOates1974226_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOates1974226-192">[183]</a></sup> The Fort Sumter attack rallied Americans north of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mason-Dixon_line" title="Mason-Dixon line">Mason-Dixon line</a> to defend the nation.
</p><p>As States sent Union regiments south, on April 19, Baltimore mobs in control of the rail links <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_riot_of_1861" title="Baltimore riot of 1861">attacked Union troops</a> who were changing trains. Local leaders' groups later burned critical rail bridges to the capital and the Army responded by arresting <a href="/wiki/Maryland_in_the_American_Civil_War#Imposition_of_martial_law" title="Maryland in the American Civil War">local Maryland</a> officials. Lincoln suspended the writ of <i><a href="/wiki/Habeas_corpus_in_the_United_States#Suspension_during_the_Civil_War" title="Habeas corpus in the United States">habeas corpus</a></i> where needed for the security of troops trying to reach Washington.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeidlerHeidlerColes2002174_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeidlerHeidlerColes2002174-193">[184]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/John_Merryman" title="John Merryman">John Merryman</a>, one Maryland official hindering the U.S. troop movements, petitioned Supreme Court Chief Justice Roger B. Taney to issue a writ of <i>habeas corpus.</i> In June, in <a href="/wiki/Ex_parte_Merryman" title="Ex parte Merryman">Ex parte Merryman</a>, Taney, not ruling on behalf of the Supreme Court,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[185]</a></sup> issued the writ, believing that Article I, section 9 of the Constitution authorized only Congress and not the president to suspend it. But Lincoln persisted with the policy of suspension in select areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris201159–71_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris201159–71-195">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeely19923–31_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeely19923–31-196">[187]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Union_military_strategy">Union military strategy</span></h4>
<p>Lincoln took executive control of the war and shaped the <a href="/wiki/Union_(American_Civil_War)" title="Union (American Civil War)">Union</a> military strategy. He responded to the unprecedented political and military crisis as <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> by exercising unprecedented authority. He expanded his war powers, imposed a blockade on Confederate ports, disbursed funds before appropriation by Congress, suspended <i>habeas corpus</i>, and arrested and imprisoned thousands of suspected Confederate sympathizers. Lincoln gained the support of Congress and the northern public for these actions. Lincoln also had to reinforce Union sympathies in the border slave states and keep the war from becoming an international conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996303–304Carwardine2003163–164_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996303–304Carwardine2003163–164-197">[188]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RunningtheMachine-LincAdmin.jpg"><img alt="A group of men sitting at a table as another man creates money on a wooden machine." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1124" data-file-width="1536" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/RunningtheMachine-LincAdmin.jpg/220px-RunningtheMachine-LincAdmin.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/RunningtheMachine-LincAdmin.jpg/330px-RunningtheMachine-LincAdmin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/RunningtheMachine-LincAdmin.jpg/440px-RunningtheMachine-LincAdmin.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RunningtheMachine-LincAdmin.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Running the Machine</i>: An 1864 political cartoon satirizing Lincoln's administration – featuring <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_Fessenden" title="William Fessenden">William Fessenden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edwin_Stanton" title="Edwin Stanton">Edwin Stanton</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_H._Seward" title="William H. Seward">William Seward</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gideon_Welles" title="Gideon Welles">Gideon Welles</a>, Lincoln, and others</div></div></div>
<p>It was clear from the outset that bipartisan support was essential to success, and that any compromise alienated factions on both sides of the aisle, such as the appointment of Republicans and Democrats to command positions. Copperheads criticized Lincoln for refusing to compromise on slavery. The Radical Republicans criticized him for moving too slowly in abolishing slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996315–339,_417_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996315–339,_417-198">[189]</a></sup> On August 6, 1861, Lincoln signed the <a href="/wiki/Confiscation_Act_of_1861" title="Confiscation Act of 1861">Confiscation Act</a> that authorized judicial proceedings to confiscate and free slaves who were used to support the Confederates. The law had little practical effect, but it signaled political support for abolishing slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996314Carwardine2003178_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996314Carwardine2003178-199">[190]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 1861, General John C. Frémont, the 1856 Republican presidential nominee, without consulting Washington, issued a martial edict freeing slaves of the rebels. Lincoln canceled the illegal proclamation as politically motivated and lacking military necessity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996314–317_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996314–317-200">[191]</a></sup> As a result, Union enlistments from Maryland, Kentucky, and Missouri increased by over 40,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarwardine2003181_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarwardine2003181-201">[192]</a></sup>
</p><p>Internationally, Lincoln wanted to forestall foreign military aid to the Confederacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBorittPinsker2002213–214_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBorittPinsker2002213–214-202">[193]</a></sup> He relied on his combative Secretary of State <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_Seward" title="William Seward">William Seward</a> while working closely with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senate_Foreign_Relations_Committee" title="Senate Foreign Relations Committee">Senate Foreign Relations Committee</a> chairman <a href="/wiki/Charles_Sumner" title="Charles Sumner">Charles Sumner</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996322_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996322-203">[194]</a></sup> In the 1861 <a href="/wiki/Trent_Affair" title="Trent Affair">Trent Affair</a> which threatened war with Great Britain, the U.S. Navy illegally intercepted a British mail ship, the <i>Trent</i>, on the high seas and seized two Confederate envoys; Britain protested vehemently while the U.S. cheered. Lincoln ended the crisis by releasing the two diplomats. Biographer <a href="/wiki/James_G._Randall" title="James G. Randall">James G. Randall</a> dissected Lincoln's successful techniques:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[195]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>his restraint, his avoidance of any outward expression of truculence, his early softening of State Department's attitude toward Britain, his deference toward Seward and Sumner, his withholding of his paper prepared for the occasion, his readiness to arbitrate, his golden silence in addressing Congress, his shrewdness in recognizing that war must be averted, and his clear perception that a point could be clinched for America's true position at the same time that satisfaction was given to a friendly country.</p></blockquote>
<p>Lincoln painstakingly monitored the telegraph reports coming into the War Department. He tracked all phases of the effort, consulting with governors, and selecting generals based on their success, their state, and their party. In January 1862, after complaints of inefficiency and profiteering in the War Department, Lincoln replaced <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_War" title="United States Secretary of War">War Secretary</a> Simon Cameron with <a href="/wiki/Edwin_Stanton" title="Edwin Stanton">Edwin Stanton</a>. Stanton centralized the War Department's activities, auditing and canceling contracts, saving the federal government $17,000,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOates1974115_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOates1974115-205">[196]</a></sup> Stanton was a staunch Unionist, pro-business, conservative Democrat who gravitated toward the Radical Republican faction. He worked more often and more closely with Lincoln than any other senior official. "Stanton and Lincoln virtually conducted the war together", say Thomas and Hyman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lincoln's war strategy embraced two priorities: ensuring that Washington was well-defended and conducting an aggressive war effort for a prompt, decisive victory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[j]</a></sup> Twice a week, Lincoln met with his cabinet in the afternoon. Occasionally Mary prevailed on him to take a carriage ride, concerned that he was working too hard.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996391–392_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996391–392-209">[199]</a></sup> For his edification Lincoln relied upon a book by his chief of staff General <a href="/wiki/Henry_Halleck" title="Henry Halleck">Henry Halleck</a> entitled <i>Elements of Military Art and Science</i>; Halleck was a disciple of the European strategist <a href="/wiki/Antoine-Henri_Jomini" title="Antoine-Henri Jomini">Antoine-Henri Jomini</a>. Lincoln began to appreciate the critical need to control strategic points, such as the <a href="/wiki/Mississippi_River" title="Mississippi River">Mississippi River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAmbrose19967,_66,_159_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAmbrose19967,_66,_159-210">[200]</a></sup> Lincoln saw the importance of <a href="/wiki/Vicksburg,_Mississippi" title="Vicksburg, Mississippi">Vicksburg</a> and understood the necessity of defeating the enemy's army, rather than simply capturing territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996432–436_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996432–436-211">[201]</a></sup>
</p><p>In directing the Union's war strategy, Lincoln valued the advice of <a href="/wiki/Winfield_Scott" title="Winfield Scott">Gen. Winfield Scott</a>, even after his retirement as <a href="/wiki/Commanding_General_of_the_United_States_Army" title="Commanding General of the United States Army">Commanding General of the United States Army</a>. On June 23–24, 1862, President Lincoln made an unannounced visit to <a href="/wiki/United_States_Military_Academy" title="United States Military Academy">West Point</a>, where he spent five hours consulting with Scott regarding the handling of the Civil War and the staffing of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_War" title="United States Department of War">War Department</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[203]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="General_McClellan">General McClellan</span></h4>
<p>After the Union rout at <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_Bull_Run" title="First Battle of Bull Run">Bull Run</a> and <a href="/wiki/Winfield_Scott" title="Winfield Scott">Winfield Scott</a>'s retirement, Lincoln appointed Major General <a href="/wiki/George_B._McClellan" title="George B. McClellan">George B. McClellan</a> general-in-chief.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996318–319_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996318–319-214">[204]</a></sup> McClellan then took months to plan his Virginia <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peninsula_Campaign" title="Peninsula Campaign">Peninsula Campaign</a>. McClellan's slow progress frustrated Lincoln, as did his position that no troops were needed to defend Washington. McClellan, in turn, blamed the failure of the campaign on Lincoln's reservation of troops for the capitol.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996349–352_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996349–352-215">[205]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_and_McClellan_1862-10-03.jpg"><img alt="Photograph of Lincoln and McClellan sitting at a table in a field tent" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="750" decoding="async" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Lincoln_and_McClellan_1862-10-03.jpg/220px-Lincoln_and_McClellan_1862-10-03.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Lincoln_and_McClellan_1862-10-03.jpg/330px-Lincoln_and_McClellan_1862-10-03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Lincoln_and_McClellan_1862-10-03.jpg/440px-Lincoln_and_McClellan_1862-10-03.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_and_McClellan_1862-10-03.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lincoln and <a href="/wiki/George_B._McClellan" title="George B. McClellan">McClellan</a>, October 3, 1862</div></div></div>
<p>In 1862, Lincoln removed McClellan for the general's continued inaction. He elevated Henry Halleck in July and appointed <a href="/wiki/John_Pope_(military_officer)" title="John Pope (military officer)">John Pope</a> as head of the new <a href="/wiki/Army_of_Virginia" title="Army of Virginia">Army of Virginia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[206]</a></sup> Pope satisfied Lincoln's desire to advance on Richmond from the north, thus protecting Washington from counterattack.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENevins1947159–162_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENevins1947159–162-217">[207]</a></sup> But Pope was then soundly defeated at the <a href="/wiki/Second_Battle_of_Bull_Run" title="Second Battle of Bull Run">Second Battle of Bull Run</a> in the summer of 1862, forcing the Army of the Potomac back to defend Washington.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENevins1959159–162_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENevins1959159–162-218">[208]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite his dissatisfaction with McClellan's failure to reinforce Pope, Lincoln restored him to command of all forces around Washington.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoodwin2005478–479_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodwin2005478–479-219">[209]</a></sup> Two days after McClellan's return to command, General <a href="/wiki/Robert_E._Lee" title="Robert E. Lee">Robert E. Lee</a>'s forces crossed the <a href="/wiki/Potomac_River" title="Potomac River">Potomac River</a> into Maryland, leading to the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Antietam" title="Battle of Antietam">Battle of Antietam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoodwin2005478–480_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodwin2005478–480-220">[210]</a></sup> That battle, a Union victory, was among the bloodiest in American history; it facilitated Lincoln's <a href="/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation" title="Emancipation Proclamation">Emancipation Proclamation</a> in January.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoodwin2005481_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodwin2005481-221">[211]</a></sup>
</p><p>McClellan then resisted the president's demand that he pursue Lee's withdrawing army, while General <a href="/wiki/Don_Carlos_Buell" title="Don Carlos Buell">Don Carlos Buell</a> likewise refused orders to move the <a href="/wiki/Army_of_the_Ohio" title="Army of the Ohio">Army of the Ohio</a> against rebel forces in eastern Tennessee. Lincoln replaced Buell with <a href="/wiki/William_Rosecrans" title="William Rosecrans">William Rosecrans</a>; and after the <a href="/wiki/1862_and_1863_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections" title="1862 and 1863 United States House of Representatives elections">1862 midterm elections</a> he replaced McClellan with <a href="/wiki/Ambrose_Burnside" title="Ambrose Burnside">Ambrose Burnside</a>. The appointments were both politically neutral and adroit on Lincoln's part.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996389–390_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996389–390-222">[212]</a></sup>
</p><p>Burnside, against presidential advice, launched an offensive across the <a href="/wiki/Rappahannock_River" title="Rappahannock River">Rappahannock River</a> and was <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fredericksburg" title="Battle of Fredericksburg">defeated by Lee at Fredericksburg</a> in December. Desertions during 1863 came in the thousands and only increased after Fredericksburg, so Lincoln replaced Burnside with <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Hooker" title="Joseph Hooker">Joseph Hooker</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENevins1947433–444Donald1996429–431_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENevins1947433–444Donald1996429–431-223">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1862 midterm elections the Republicans suffered severe losses due to rising inflation, high taxes, rumors of corruption, suspension of <i>habeas corpus</i>, <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">military draft law</a>, and fears that freed slaves would come North and undermine the labor market. The Emancipation Proclamation gained votes for Republicans in rural New England and the upper Midwest, but cost votes in the Irish and German strongholds and in the lower Midwest, where many Southerners had lived for generations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENevins1947322_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENevins1947322-224">[214]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the spring of 1863 Lincoln was sufficiently optimistic about upcoming military campaigns to think the end of the war could be near; the plans included attacks by Hooker on Lee north of Richmond, Rosecrans on Chattanooga, <a href="/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant" title="Ulysses S. Grant">Grant</a> on Vicksburg, and a naval assault on Charleston.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996422–423_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996422–423-225">[215]</a></sup>
</p><p>Hooker was routed by Lee at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Chancellorsville" title="Battle of Chancellorsville">Battle of Chancellorsville</a> in May, then resigned and was replaced by <a href="/wiki/George_Meade" title="George Meade">George Meade</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENevins1947432–450_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENevins1947432–450-226">[216]</a></sup> Meade followed Lee north into Pennsylvania and beat him in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gettysburg_Campaign" title="Gettysburg Campaign">Gettysburg Campaign</a>, but then failed to follow up despite Lincoln's demands. At the same time, Grant captured Vicksburg and gained control of the Mississippi River, splitting the far western rebel states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996444–447_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996444–447-227">[217]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Emancipation_Proclamation">Emancipation Proclamation</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln_and_slavery" title="Abraham Lincoln and slavery">Abraham Lincoln and slavery</a> and <a href="/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation" title="Emancipation Proclamation">Emancipation Proclamation</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><div class="noresize"><map name="ImageMap_ab2b7974f65b6987"><area alt="Edwin Stanton" coords="50,167,47,145,36,138,24,135,8,114,4,90,9,85,14,81,11,70,21,64,25,68,27,79,40,99,57,123,67,126,76,164" href="/wiki/Edwin_M._Stanton" shape="poly" title="Edwin Stanton"/><area alt="Salmon Chase" coords="32,53,32,46,46,38,46,28,49,22,55,23,57,31,57,38,60,44,66,55,70,65,63,74,64,88" href="/wiki/Salmon_P._Chase" shape="poly" title="Salmon Chase"/><area alt="Abraham Lincoln" coords="106,167,100,132,80,114,67,105,70,85,73,75,87,66,84,59,88,48,97,48,102,53,99,63,98,70,104,75,111,80,119,92,134,101,129,103,129,108,125,102,116,103,111,115,130,117,127,159" href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" shape="poly" title="Abraham Lincoln"/><area alt="Gideon Welles" coords="129,96,138,82,147,76,144,65,149,57,155,55,161,61,162,71,162,76,171,80,171,88,158,99,152,100,132,100" href="/wiki/Gideon_Welles" shape="poly" title="Gideon Welles"/><area alt="William Seward" coords="131,146,140,144,154,117,169,116,173,106,169,100,165,105,156,105,163,94,174,84,195,76,195,73,193,71,195,68,198,63,196,62,196,61,202,59,210,63,212,70,208,77,211,87,214,95,209,110,203,118,202,132" href="/wiki/William_H._Seward" shape="poly" title="William Seward"/><area alt="Caleb Smith" coords="169,78,176,61,184,55,186,53,183,46,185,38,193,39,195,46,196,53,199,58,200,59,196,61,195,66,193,72,193,76,172,85" href="/wiki/Caleb_Blood_Smith" shape="poly" title="Caleb Smith"/><area alt="Montgomery Blair" coords="202,58,206,48,204,41,204,34,207,30,214,30,218,36,215,42,215,46,224,50,230,58,231,70,231,83,228,91,210,84,209,77,212,71,210,64" href="/wiki/Montgomery_Blair" shape="poly" title="Montgomery Blair"/><area alt="Edward Bates" coords="229,89,242,78,244,71,242,61,247,58,254,61,256,67,256,72,256,74,264,79,266,93,269,105,252,104,230,97" href="/wiki/Edward_Bates" shape="poly" title="Edward Bates"/><area alt="Emancipation Proclamation" coords="117,104,111,116,131,117,136,103" href="/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation" shape="poly" title="Emancipation Proclamation"/><area alt="Portrait of Simon Cameron" coords="22,15,22,56,1,56,1,15" href="/wiki/Simon_Cameron" shape="poly" title="Portrait of Simon Cameron"/><area alt="Portrait of Andrew Jackson" coords="140,37,179,35,177,1,137,2" href="/wiki/Andrew_Jackson" shape="poly" title="Portrait of Andrew Jackson"/></map><img alt="A dark-haired, bearded, middle-aged man holding documents is seated among seven other men." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="915" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Emancipation_proclamation.jpg/280px-Emancipation_proclamation.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Emancipation_proclamation.jpg/420px-Emancipation_proclamation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Emancipation_proclamation.jpg/560px-Emancipation_proclamation.jpg 2x" usemap="#ImageMap_ab2b7974f65b6987" width="280"/></div> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Emancipation_proclamation.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/First_Reading_of_the_Emancipation_Proclamation_of_President_Lincoln" title="First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation of President Lincoln">First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation of President Lincoln</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Francis_Bicknell_Carpenter" title="Francis Bicknell Carpenter">Francis Bicknell Carpenter</a> (1864) <small><i>(Clickable image—use cursor to identify.)</i></small></div></div></div>
<p>The Federal government's power to end slavery was limited by the Constitution, which before 1865 was understood to reserve the issue to the individual states. Lincoln believed that slavery would be rendered obsolete if its expansion into new territories were prevented, because these territories would be admitted to the Union as free states, and free states would come to outnumber slave states. He sought to persuade the states to agree to <a href="/wiki/Compensated_emancipation" title="Compensated emancipation">compensation</a> for emancipating their slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mackubin_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mackubin-228">[218]</a></sup> Lincoln rejected Major General <a href="/wiki/John_C._Fr%C3%A9mont" title="John C. Frémont">John C. Frémont</a>'s August 1861 <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9mont_Emancipation" title="Frémont Emancipation">emancipation</a> attempt, as well as one by Major General <a href="/wiki/David_Hunter" title="David Hunter">David Hunter</a> in May 1862, on the grounds that it was not within their power and might upset loyal border states enough for them to secede.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGuelzo1999290–291_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGuelzo1999290–291-229">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 1862, Congress passed an act banning slavery on all federal territory, which Lincoln signed. In July, the <a href="/wiki/Confiscation_Act_of_1862" title="Confiscation Act of 1862">Confiscation Act of 1862</a> was enacted, providing court procedures to free the slaves of those convicted of aiding the rebellion; Lincoln approved the bill despite his belief that it was unconstitutional. He felt such action could be taken only within the war powers of the commander-in-chief, which he planned to exercise. Lincoln at this time reviewed a draft of the Emancipation Proclamation with his cabinet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996364–365_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996364–365-230">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>Privately, Lincoln concluded that the Confederacy's slave base had to be eliminated. Copperheads argued that emancipation was a stumbling block to peace and reunification; Republican editor <a href="/wiki/Horace_Greeley" title="Horace Greeley">Horace Greeley</a> of the <i>New York Tribune</i> agreed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcPherson1992124_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcPherson1992124-231">[221]</a></sup> In a letter of August 22, 1862, Lincoln said that while he personally wished all men could be free, regardless of that, his first obligation as president was to preserve the Union:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGuelzo2004147–153_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGuelzo2004147–153-232">[222]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>My paramount object in this struggle is to save the Union, and is not either to save or to destroy slavery. If I could save the Union without freeing any slave I would do it, and if I could save it by freeing all the slaves I would do it; and if I could save it by freeing some and leaving others alone I would also do that. What I do about slavery, and the colored race, I do because I believe it helps to save the Union; and what I forbear, I forbear because I do not believe it would help to save the Union ... [¶] I have here stated my purpose according to my view of official duty; and I intend no modification of my oft-expressed personal wish that all men everywhere could be free.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGraebner1959388_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraebner1959388-233">[223]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>On September 22, 1862, Lincoln issued the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[224]</a></sup> which announced that, in states still in rebellion on January 1, 1863, the slaves would be freed. He kept his word and, on January 1, 1863, issued the Emancipation Proclamation,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[225]</a></sup> freeing the slaves in 10 states not then under Union control,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[226]</a></sup> with exemptions specified for areas under such control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996379_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996379-237">[227]</a></sup> Lincoln's comment on signing the Proclamation was: "I never, in my life, felt more certain that I was doing right, than I do in signing this paper."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996407_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996407-238">[228]</a></sup> He spent the next 100 days preparing the army and the nation for emancipation, while Democrats rallied their voters by warning of the threat that freed slaves posed to northern whites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[229]</a></sup>
</p><p>With the abolition of slavery in the rebel states now a military objective, Union armies advancing south liberated all three million slaves in the Confederacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[230]</a></sup> The Emancipation Proclamation having stated that freedmen would be "received into the armed service of the United States," enlisting these freedmen became official policy. By the spring of 1863, Lincoln was ready to recruit black troops in more than token numbers. In a letter to Tennessee military governor <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Johnson" title="Andrew Johnson">Andrew Johnson</a> encouraging him to lead the way in raising black troops, Lincoln wrote, "The bare sight of 50,000 armed and drilled black soldiers on the banks of the Mississippi would end the rebellion at once".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996430–431_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996430–431-241">[231]</a></sup> By the end of 1863, at Lincoln's direction, General <a href="/wiki/Lorenzo_Thomas" title="Lorenzo Thomas">Lorenzo Thomas</a> had recruited 20 regiments of blacks from the Mississippi Valley.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996431_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996431-242">[232]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Gettysburg_Address_.281863.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Gettysburg_Address_(1863)">Gettysburg Address (1863)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Gettysburg_Address" title="Gettysburg Address">Gettysburg Address</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln%27s_Gettysburg_Address,_Gettysburg,_highlighted_version.png"><img alt="Large group of people" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6064" data-file-width="7499" decoding="async" height="210" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Lincoln%27s_Gettysburg_Address%2C_Gettysburg%2C_highlighted_version.png/260px-Lincoln%27s_Gettysburg_Address%2C_Gettysburg%2C_highlighted_version.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Lincoln%27s_Gettysburg_Address%2C_Gettysburg%2C_highlighted_version.png/390px-Lincoln%27s_Gettysburg_Address%2C_Gettysburg%2C_highlighted_version.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Lincoln%27s_Gettysburg_Address%2C_Gettysburg%2C_highlighted_version.png/520px-Lincoln%27s_Gettysburg_Address%2C_Gettysburg%2C_highlighted_version.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln%27s_Gettysburg_Address,_Gettysburg,_highlighted_version.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lincoln (absent his usual <a href="/wiki/Top_hat" title="Top hat">top hat</a> and highlighted in red) at <a href="/wiki/Gettysburg_Battlefield" title="Gettysburg Battlefield">Gettysburg</a> on November 19, 1863. Roughly three hours later, he delivered the <a href="/wiki/Gettysburg_Address" title="Gettysburg Address">Gettysburg Address</a>, one of the best known speeches in <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_States" title="History of the United States">American history</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[234]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Lincoln spoke at the dedication of the Gettysburg battlefield cemetery on November 19, 1863.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996453–460_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996453–460-245">[235]</a></sup> In 272 words, and three minutes, Lincoln asserted that the nation was born not in 1789, but in 1776, "conceived in Liberty, and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal". He defined the war as dedicated to the principles of liberty and equality for all. He declared that the deaths of so many brave soldiers would not be in vain, that slavery would end, and the future of democracy would be assured, that "government of the people, by the people, for the people, shall not perish from the earth".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996460–466Wills201220,_27,_105,_146_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996460–466Wills201220,_27,_105,_146-246">[236]</a></sup>
</p><p>Defying his prediction that "the world will little note, nor long remember what we say here", the Address became the most quoted speech in American history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBullaBorchard2010222_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBullaBorchard2010222-247">[237]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Promoting_General_Grant">Promoting General Grant</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><div class="noresize"><map name="ImageMap_7b6a39bccc9d9f4f"><area alt="General Sherman" coords="45,66,54,63,62,69,64,80,61,87,54,90,69,106,73,97,75,89,85,84,84,96,80,122,54,114,48,128,58,129,64,137,79,141,94,190,108,200,81,199,67,157,62,157,59,187,68,189,46,195,47,168,34,166,25,159,21,141,24,114,25,98,30,88,40,85,45,81,42,73" href="/wiki/William_Tecumseh_Sherman" shape="poly" title="General Sherman"/><area alt="General Grant" coords="102,74,110,77,111,83,108,90,114,95,124,110,133,108,138,114,129,140,134,144,130,146,130,167,133,170,129,174,121,171,119,147,116,143,116,138,102,139,92,148,86,106,90,96,98,92,96,85,96,78" href="/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant" shape="poly" title="General Grant"/><area alt="President Lincoln" coords="152,75,160,72,167,77,168,89,180,90,205,100,204,111,197,126,189,130,190,144,156,144,162,182,142,181,147,175,151,173,149,161,146,176,130,180,131,175,136,169,145,124,146,118,149,110,156,91,151,83" href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" shape="poly" title="President Lincoln"/><area alt="Admiral Porter" coords="244,73,256,72,257,83,256,92,266,99,267,123,261,132,258,141,262,149,259,181,248,179,240,167,234,166,233,160,229,163,233,191,219,200,215,198,219,190,214,164,208,194,184,194,186,190,192,187,195,183,203,143,230,133,229,120,220,129,213,125,214,120,220,112,225,110,233,106,237,100,239,92,242,78" href="/wiki/David_Dixon_Porter" shape="poly" title="Admiral Porter"/></map><img alt="Painting of four men conferring in a ship's cabin, entitled &quot;The Peacemakers&quot;." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2254" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="210" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/The_Peacemakers_1868.jpg/280px-The_Peacemakers_1868.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/The_Peacemakers_1868.jpg/420px-The_Peacemakers_1868.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/The_Peacemakers_1868.jpg/560px-The_Peacemakers_1868.jpg 2x" usemap="#ImageMap_7b6a39bccc9d9f4f" width="280"/></div> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Peacemakers_1868.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Peacemakers" title="The Peacemakers">The Peacemakers</a></i>, an 1868 painting by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/George_P.A._Healy" title="George P.A. Healy">George P.A. Healy</a> of events aboard the <i><a href="/wiki/River_Queen_(steamboat)" title="River Queen (steamboat)">River Queen</a></i> in March 1865 <small><i>(Clickable image—use cursor to identify.)</i></small></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant" title="Ulysses S. Grant">General Ulysses Grant's</a> victories at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Shiloh" title="Battle of Shiloh">Battle of Shiloh</a> and in the <a href="/wiki/Vicksburg_campaign" title="Vicksburg campaign">Vicksburg campaign</a> impressed Lincoln. Responding to criticism of Grant after Shiloh, Lincoln had said, "I can't spare this man. He fights."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThomas2008315_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas2008315-248">[238]</a></sup> With Grant in command, Lincoln felt the Union Army could advance in multiple theaters, while also including black troops. Meade's failure to capture Lee's army after Gettysburg and the continued passivity of the Army of the Potomac persuaded Lincoln to promote Grant to supreme commander. Grant then assumed command of Meade's army.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENevins19474:6–17_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENevins19474:6–17-249">[239]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lincoln was concerned that Grant might be considering a presidential candidacy in 1864. He arranged for an intermediary to inquire into Grant's political intentions, and once assured that he had none, Lincoln promoted Grant to the newly revived rank of Lieutenant General, a rank which had been unoccupied since <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996490–492_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996490–492-250">[240]</a></sup> Authorization for such a promotion "with the advice and consent of the Senate" was provided by a new bill which Lincoln signed the same day he submitted Grant's name to the Senate. His nomination was confirmed by the Senate on March 2, 1864.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[241]</a></sup>
</p><p>Grant in 1864 waged the bloody <a href="/wiki/Overland_Campaign" title="Overland Campaign">Overland Campaign</a>, which exacted heavy losses on both sides.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcPherson2009113_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcPherson2009113-252">[242]</a></sup> When Lincoln asked what Grant's plans were, the persistent general replied, "I propose to fight it out on this line if it takes all summer."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996501_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996501-253">[243]</a></sup> Grant's army moved steadily south. Lincoln traveled to Grant's headquarters at <a href="/wiki/City_Point,_Virginia" title="City Point, Virginia">City Point, Virginia</a>, to confer with Grant and William Tecumseh Sherman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whitehousehistory_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-whitehousehistory-254">[244]</a></sup> Lincoln reacted to Union losses by mobilizing support throughout the North.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThomas2008422–424_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas2008422–424-255">[245]</a></sup> Lincoln authorized Grant to target infrastructure—plantations, railroads, and bridges—hoping to weaken the South's morale and fighting ability. He emphasized defeat of the Confederate armies over destruction (which was considerable) for its own sake.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeely2004434–458_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeely2004434–458-256">[246]</a></sup> Lincoln's engagement became distinctly personal on one occasion in 1864 when Confederate general <a href="/wiki/Jubal_Early" title="Jubal Early">Jubal Early</a> <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Stevens" title="Battle of Fort Stevens">raided Washington, D.C.</a> Legend has it that while Lincoln watched from an exposed position, Union Captain (and future <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">Supreme Court Justice</a>) <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Wendell_Holmes_Jr." title="Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr.">Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr.</a> shouted at him, "Get down, you damn fool, before you get shot!"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThomas2008434_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas2008434-257">[247]</a></sup>
</p><p>As Grant continued to weaken Lee's forces, efforts to discuss peace began. Confederate Vice President <a href="/wiki/Alexander_H._Stephens" title="Alexander H. Stephens">Stephens</a> led a group meeting with Lincoln, Seward, and others at <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Roads_Conference" title="Hampton Roads Conference">Hampton Roads</a>. Lincoln refused to negotiate with the Confederacy as a coequal; his objective to end the fighting was not realized.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996565_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996565-258">[248]</a></sup> On April 1, 1865, Grant nearly encircled Petersburg in a siege. The Confederate government evacuated Richmond and Lincoln visited the conquered capital. On April 9, Lee surrendered to Grant at <a href="/wiki/Appomattox_Court_House_National_Historical_Park" title="Appomattox Court House National Historical Park">Appomattox</a>, officially ending the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996589_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996589-259">[249]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reelection">Reelection</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/1864_United_States_presidential_election" title="1864 United States presidential election">1864 United States presidential election</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege1864.svg"><img alt="Map of the U.S. showing Lincoln winning all the Union states except for Kentucky, New Jersey, and Delaware. The Southern states are not included." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="1020" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/ElectoralCollege1864.svg/290px-ElectoralCollege1864.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/ElectoralCollege1864.svg/435px-ElectoralCollege1864.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/ElectoralCollege1864.svg/580px-ElectoralCollege1864.svg.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege1864.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electoral_College_(United_States)" title="Electoral College (United States)">electoral</a> landslide for Lincoln (in red) in the 1864 election; southern states (brown) and territories (gray) not in play</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Republican_presidential_ticket_1864b.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5052" data-file-width="3592" decoding="async" height="309" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Republican_presidential_ticket_1864b.jpg/220px-Republican_presidential_ticket_1864b.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Republican_presidential_ticket_1864b.jpg/330px-Republican_presidential_ticket_1864b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Republican_presidential_ticket_1864b.jpg/440px-Republican_presidential_ticket_1864b.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Republican_presidential_ticket_1864b.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A poster of the 1864 election campaign with <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Johnson" title="Andrew Johnson">Andrew Johnson</a> as the candidate for vice president</div></div></div>
