<td><a href="/wiki/Salmon_P._Chase" title="Salmon P. Chase">Salmon Portland Chase</a> (Chief Justice)
</td>
<td>December 6, 1864
</td>
<td>December 6, 1864
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Lincoln's philosophy on court nominations was that "we cannot ask a man what he will do, and if we should, and he should answer us, we should despise him for it. Therefore we must take a man whose opinions are known."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996471_304-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996471-304">[294]</a></sup> Lincoln made five appointments to the Supreme Court. <a href="/wiki/Noah_Haynes_Swayne" title="Noah Haynes Swayne">Noah Haynes Swayne</a> was an anti-slavery lawyer who was committed to the Union. <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Freeman_Miller" title="Samuel Freeman Miller">Samuel Freeman Miller</a> supported Lincoln in the 1860 election and was an avowed abolitionist. David Davis was Lincoln's campaign manager in 1860 and had served as a judge in the Illinois court circuit where Lincoln practiced. Democrat <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Johnson_Field" title="Stephen Johnson Field">Stephen Johnson Field</a>, a previous California Supreme Court justice, provided geographic and political balance. Finally, Lincoln's Treasury Secretary, Salmon P. Chase, became Chief Justice. Lincoln believed Chase was an able jurist, would support Reconstruction legislation, and that his appointment united the Republican Party.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlue1987245_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlue1987245-306">[296]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_policy">Foreign policy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Abraham_Lincoln#Foreign_policy" title="Presidency of Abraham Lincoln">Presidency of Abraham Lincoln § Foreign policy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Diplomacy_of_the_American_Civil_War" title="Diplomacy of the American Civil War">Diplomacy of the American Civil War</a></div>
<p>Lincoln named his main political rival William H. Seward as Secretary of State, and left most diplomatic issues in his portfolio. However Lincoln did select some of the top diplomats as part of his patronage policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[297]</a></sup>  He also closely watched the handling of the <a href="/wiki/Trent_Affair" title="Trent Affair">Trent Affair</a> in late 1861 to make sure there was no escalation into a war with Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[298]</a></sup> Seward's main role was to keep Britain and France from supporting the Confederacy. He was successful after indicating to London and Paris that Washington would declare war on them if they supported Richmond.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[299]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Assassination">Assassination</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Assassination of Abraham Lincoln">Assassination of Abraham Lincoln</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900_-_Restoration.jpg"><img alt="Painting of Lincoln being shot by Booth while sitting in a theater booth." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1780" data-file-width="1903" decoding="async" height="206" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900_-_Restoration.jpg/220px-Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900_-_Restoration.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900_-_Restoration.jpg/330px-Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900_-_Restoration.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900_-_Restoration.jpg/440px-Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900_-_Restoration.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900_-_Restoration.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Shown in the presidential booth of Ford's Theatre, from left to right, are assassin <a href="/wiki/John_Wilkes_Booth" title="John Wilkes Booth">John Wilkes Booth</a>, Abraham Lincoln, <a href="/wiki/Mary_Todd_Lincoln" title="Mary Todd Lincoln">Mary Todd Lincoln</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clara_Harris" title="Clara Harris">Clara Harris</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Rathbone" title="Henry Rathbone">Henry Rathbone</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/John_Wilkes_Booth" title="John Wilkes Booth">John Wilkes Booth</a> was a well-known actor and a Confederate spy from Maryland; though he never joined the Confederate army, he had contacts with the Confederate secret service.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996586–587_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996586–587-310">[300]</a></sup> After attending an April 11, 1865 speech in which Lincoln promoted voting rights for blacks, Booth hatched a plot to assassinate the President.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarrison20103–4_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarrison20103–4-311">[301]</a></sup> When Booth learned of the Lincolns' intent to attend a play with General Grant, he planned to assassinate Lincoln and Grant at <a href="/wiki/Ford%27s_Theatre" title="Ford's Theatre">Ford's Theatre</a>. Lincoln and his wife attended the play <i><a href="/wiki/Our_American_Cousin" title="Our American Cousin">Our American Cousin</a></i> on the evening of April 14, just five days after the Union victory at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Appomattox_Courthouse" title="Battle of Appomattox Courthouse">Battle of Appomattox Courthouse</a>. At the last minute, Grant decided to go to New Jersey to visit his children instead of attending the play.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996594–597_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996594–597-312">[302]</a></sup>
</p><p>On April 14, 1865, hours before he was assassinated, Lincoln signed legislation establishing the United States Secret Service,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[303]</a></sup> and, at 10:15 in the evening, Booth entered the back of Lincoln's theater box, crept up from behind, and fired at the back of Lincoln's head, mortally wounding him. Lincoln's guest, Major <a href="/wiki/Henry_Rathbone" title="Henry Rathbone">Henry Rathbone</a>, momentarily grappled with Booth, but Booth stabbed him and escaped.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996597Martin2010_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996597Martin2010-314">[304]</a></sup> After being attended by <a href="/wiki/Charles_Leale" title="Charles Leale">Doctor Charles Leale</a> and two other doctors, Lincoln was taken across the street to <a href="/wiki/Petersen_House" title="Petersen House">Petersen House</a>. After remaining in a <a href="/wiki/Coma" title="Coma">coma</a> for eight hours, Lincoln died at 7:22 in the morning on April 15.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteers2010153_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteers2010153-315">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[k]</a></sup> Stanton saluted and said, "Now he belongs to the ages."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996598–599,_686_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996598–599,_686-321">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[l]</a></sup> Lincoln's body was placed in a flag-wrapped coffin, which was loaded into a hearse and escorted to the White House by Union soldiers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[311]</a></sup> President Johnson was sworn in later that same day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[312]</a></sup>
</p><p>Two weeks later, Booth, refusing to surrender, was tracked to a farm in Virginia, and was mortally shot by Sergeant <a href="/wiki/Boston_Corbett" title="Boston Corbett">Boston Corbett</a> and died on April 26. Secretary of War Stanton had issued orders that Booth be taken alive, so Corbett was initially arrested to be court martialed. After a brief interview, Stanton declared him a patriot and dismissed the charge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteers2010153Donald1996599_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteers2010153Donald1996599-325">[313]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Funeral_and_burial">Funeral and burial</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LincolnTrain.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="479" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/LincolnTrain.jpeg/220px-LincolnTrain.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/LincolnTrain.jpeg/330px-LincolnTrain.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/LincolnTrain.jpeg/440px-LincolnTrain.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LincolnTrain.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>This funeral train, called the <i>Lincoln Special</i>, carried Lincoln's body on the three week trip from <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> to <a href="/wiki/Springfield,_Illinois" title="Springfield, Illinois">Springfield, Illinois</a>. Along the way, it was met by hundreds of thousands of American mourners.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Funeral_and_burial_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Funeral and burial of Abraham Lincoln">Funeral and burial of Abraham Lincoln</a></div>
<p>The late President lay in state, first in the East Room of the White House, and then in the Capitol Rotunda from April 19 through April 21. The caskets containing Lincoln's body and the body of his son Willie traveled for three weeks on the <i>Lincoln Special</i> <a href="/wiki/Funeral_and_burial_of_Abraham_Lincoln#Funeral_train_to_Springfield,_Illinois" title="Funeral and burial of Abraham Lincoln">funeral train</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrostel200231–58_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrostel200231–58-326">[314]</a></sup> The train followed a circuitous route from Washington D.C. to Springfield, Illinois, stopping at many cities for memorials attended by hundreds of thousands. Many others gathered along the tracks as the train passed with bands, bonfires, and hymn singing<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrostel200231–58Goodrich2005231–238_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrostel200231–58Goodrich2005231–238-327">[315]</a></sup> or in silent grief. Poet <a href="/wiki/Walt_Whitman" title="Walt Whitman">Walt Whitman</a> composed "<a href="/wiki/When_Lilacs_Last_in_the_Dooryard_Bloom%27d" title="When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom'd">When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom'd</a>" to eulogize him, one of <a href="/wiki/Walt_Whitman_and_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Walt Whitman and Abraham Lincoln">four poems he wrote about Lincoln</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[316]</a></sup> African Americans were especially moved; they had lost 'their <a href="/wiki/Moses" title="Moses">Moses</a>'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHodes2015164_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHodes2015164-329">[317]</a></sup> In a larger sense, the reaction was in response to the deaths of so many men in the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHodes2015197–199_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHodes2015197–199-330">[318]</a></sup> Historians emphasized the widespread shock and sorrow, but noted that some Lincoln haters celebrated his death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHodes201584,_86,_96–97_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHodes201584,_86,_96–97-331">[319]</a></sup> Lincoln's body was buried at <a href="/wiki/Oak_Ridge_Cemetery" title="Oak Ridge Cemetery">Oak Ridge Cemetery</a> in Springfield and now lies within the <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Tomb" title="Lincoln Tomb">Lincoln Tomb</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[320]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Religious_and_philosophical_beliefs">Religious and philosophical beliefs</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Religious_views_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Religious views of Abraham Lincoln">Religious views of Abraham Lincoln</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AbrahamLincolnOilPainting1869Restored.jpg"><img alt="Lincoln sitting with his hand on his chin and his elbow on his leg." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2970" data-file-width="2233" decoding="async" height="226" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/AbrahamLincolnOilPainting1869Restored.jpg/170px-AbrahamLincolnOilPainting1869Restored.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/AbrahamLincolnOilPainting1869Restored.jpg/255px-AbrahamLincolnOilPainting1869Restored.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/AbrahamLincolnOilPainting1869Restored.jpg/340px-AbrahamLincolnOilPainting1869Restored.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:AbrahamLincolnOilPainting1869Restored.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln_(Healy)" title="Abraham Lincoln (Healy)">Abraham Lincoln</a></i>, painting by <a href="/wiki/George_Peter_Alexander_Healy" title="George Peter Alexander Healy">George Peter Alexander Healy</a> in 1869</div></div></div>
<p>As a young man, Lincoln was a <a href="/wiki/Religious_skepticism" title="Religious skepticism">religious skeptic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarwardine20034Wilson199984_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarwardine20034Wilson199984-333">[321]</a></sup> He was deeply familiar with the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a>, quoting and praising it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199648–49,_514–515_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199648–49,_514–515-334">[322]</a></sup> He was private about his position on organized religion and respected the beliefs of others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[323]</a></sup> He never made a clear profession of Christian beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENoll1992_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENoll1992-336">[324]</a></sup> Throughout his public career, Lincoln often quoted Scripture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[325]</a></sup> His three most famous speeches—<a href="/wiki/Lincoln%27s_House_Divided_Speech" title="Lincoln's House Divided Speech">the House Divided Speech</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gettysburg_Address" title="Gettysburg Address">the Gettysburg Address</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln%27s_second_inaugural_address" title="Abraham Lincoln's second inaugural address">his second inaugural</a>—each contain direct allusions to Providence and quotes from Scripture.
</p><p>In the 1840s, Lincoln subscribed to the <a href="/wiki/The_Doctrine_of_Philosophical_Necessity_Illustrated" title="The Doctrine of Philosophical Necessity Illustrated">Doctrine of Necessity</a>, a belief that the human mind was controlled by a higher power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199648–49_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199648–49-338">[326]</a></sup> With the death of his son Edward in 1850 he more frequently expressed a dependence on God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParrillo2000227–253_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParrillo2000227–253-339">[327]</a></sup> He never joined a church, although he frequently attended <a href="/wiki/First_Presbyterian_Church_(Springfield,_Illinois)" title="First Presbyterian Church (Springfield, Illinois)">First Presbyterian Church</a> with his wife beginning in 1852.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite2009180_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite2009180-340">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[m]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1850s, Lincoln asserted his belief in "providence" in a general way, and rarely used the language or imagery of the evangelicals; he regarded the republicanism of the Founding Fathers with an almost religious reverence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[329]</a></sup> The death of son Willie in February 1862 may have caused him to look toward religion for solace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilson1999251–254_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilson1999251–254-343">[330]</a></sup> After Willie's death, he questioned the divine necessity of the war's severity. He wrote at this time that God "could have either saved or destroyed the Union without a human contest. Yet the contest began. And having begun, He could give the final victory to either side any day. Yet the contest proceeds."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilson1999254_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilson1999254-344">[331]</a></sup>
</p><p>
Lincoln did believe in an all-powerful God that shaped events and by 1865 was expressing those beliefs in major speeches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENoll1992_336-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENoll1992-336">[324]</a></sup> By the end of the war, he increasingly appealed to the Almighty for solace and to explain events, writing on April 4, 1864, to a newspaper editor in Kentucky: <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></p><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>I claim not to have controlled events, but confess plainly that events have controlled me. Now, at the end of three years struggle the nation's condition is not what either party, or any man devised, or expected. God alone can claim it. Whither it is tending seems plain. If God now wills the removal of a great wrong, and wills also that we of the North as well as you of the South, shall pay fairly for our complicity in that wrong, impartial history will find therein new cause to attest and revere the justice and goodness of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[332]</a></sup></p></blockquote><p>This spirituality can best be seen in his second inaugural address, considered by some scholars<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[333]</a></sup> as the greatest such address in American history, and by Lincoln himself as his own greatest speech, or one of them at the very least.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[n]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[334]</a></sup> Lincoln explains therein that the cause, purpose, and result of the war was God's will.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[335]</a></sup> Lincoln's frequent use of religious imagery and language toward the end of his life may have reflected his own personal beliefs or might have been a device to reach his audiences, who were mostly <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">evangelical</a> <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarwardine200327–55_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarwardine200327–55-350">[336]</a></sup> On the day Lincoln was assassinated, he reportedly told his wife he desired to visit the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Land" title="Holy Land">Holy Land</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGuelzo1999434_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGuelzo1999434-351">[337]</a></sup>
</p><h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Health of Abraham Lincoln">Health of Abraham Lincoln</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_O-116_by_Gardner,_1865-crop.png"><img alt="An older, tired-looking Abraham Lincoln with a beard." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1115" data-file-width="892" decoding="async" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Abraham_Lincoln_O-116_by_Gardner%2C_1865-crop.png/170px-Abraham_Lincoln_O-116_by_Gardner%2C_1865-crop.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Abraham_Lincoln_O-116_by_Gardner%2C_1865-crop.png/255px-Abraham_Lincoln_O-116_by_Gardner%2C_1865-crop.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Abraham_Lincoln_O-116_by_Gardner%2C_1865-crop.png/340px-Abraham_Lincoln_O-116_by_Gardner%2C_1865-crop.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_O-116_by_Gardner,_1865-crop.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lincoln in February 1865, two months before his death</div></div></div>
<p>Lincoln is believed to have had <a href="/wiki/Depression_(mood)" title="Depression (mood)">depression</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Newsweek_-_DNA_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-Newsweek_-_DNA-352">[338]</a></sup> He took <a href="/wiki/Blue_mass" title="Blue mass">blue mass</a> pills, which contained <a href="/wiki/Mercury_(element)" title="Mercury (element)">mercury</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hirschhorn_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hirschhorn-353">[339]</a></sup> to treat <a href="/wiki/Constipation" title="Constipation">constipation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[340]</a></sup> It is unknown to what extent that might have resulted in <a href="/wiki/Mercury_poisoning" title="Mercury poisoning">mercury poisoning</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several claims have been made that Lincoln's health was declining before the assassination. These are often based on <a href="/wiki/List_of_photographs_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="List of photographs of Abraham Lincoln">photographs of Lincoln</a> appearing to show weight loss and muscle wasting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theatlantic.com_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-theatlantic.com-356">[342]</a></sup> It is also suspected that he might have had a rare genetic disease such as <a href="/wiki/Marfan_syndrome" title="Marfan syndrome">Marfan syndrome</a> or <a href="/wiki/Multiple_endocrine_neoplasia_type_2B" title="Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B">multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theatlantic.com_356-1"><a href="#cite_note-theatlantic.com-356">[342]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Cultural_depictions_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Cultural depictions of Abraham Lincoln">Cultural depictions of Abraham Lincoln</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Republican_values">Republican values</span></h3>
<p>Lincoln's redefinition of <i><a href="/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States" title="Republicanism in the United States">republican values</a></i> has been stressed by historians such as <a href="/wiki/John_Patrick_Diggins" title="John Patrick Diggins">John Patrick Diggins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harry_V._Jaffa" title="Harry V. Jaffa">Harry V. Jaffa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vernon_Burton" title="Vernon Burton">Vernon Burton</a>, Eric Foner, and Herman J. Belz.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThomas200861_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas200861-357">[343]</a></sup> Lincoln called the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">Declaration of Independence</a>—which emphasized freedom and equality for all—the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sheet_anchor" title="Sheet anchor">sheet anchor</a>" of republicanism beginning in the 1850s. He did this at a time when the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States" title="Constitution of the United States">Constitution</a>, which "tolerated slavery", was the focus of most political discourse.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJaffa2000399Thomas200861_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJaffa2000399Thomas200861-358">[344]</a></sup> Diggins notes, "Lincoln presented Americans a theory of history that offers a profound contribution to the theory and destiny of republicanism itself" in the 1860 Cooper Union speech.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiggins1986307Thomas200861_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiggins1986307Thomas200861-359">[345]</a></sup> Instead of focusing on the legality of an argument, he focused on the moral basis of republicanism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFoner2010215Thomas200861_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFoner2010215Thomas200861-360">[346]</a></sup>
</p><p>His position on war was founded on a legal argument regarding the Constitution as essentially a contract among the states, and all parties must agree to pull out of the contract. Furthermore, it was a national duty to ensure the republic stands in every state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJaffa2000263Thomas200861_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJaffa2000263Thomas200861-361">[347]</a></sup> Many soldiers and religious leaders from the north, though, felt the fight for liberty and freedom of slaves was ordained by their moral and religious beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[348]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a Whig activist, Lincoln was a spokesman for business interests, favoring high tariffs, banks, infrastructure improvements, and railroads, in opposition to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jacksonian_democrats" title="Jacksonian democrats">Jacksonian democrats</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBorittPinsker2002196–198,_229–231,_301_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBorittPinsker2002196–198,_229–231,_301-363">[349]</a></sup> Lincoln shared the sympathies that the Jacksonians professed for the common man, but he disagreed with the Jacksonian view that <a href="/wiki/Laissez-faire" title="Laissez-faire">the government should be divorced from economic enterprise</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECurrent1999_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurrent1999-364">[350]</a></sup> Nevertheless, Lincoln admired <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Jackson" title="Andrew Jackson">Andrew Jackson</a>'s steeliness as well as his patriotism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilentz2012_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilentz2012-365">[351]</a></sup> According to historian <a href="/wiki/Sean_Wilentz" title="Sean Wilentz">Sean Wilentz</a>:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilentz2012_365-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilentz2012-365">[351]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Just as the Republican Party of the 1850s absorbed certain elements of Jacksonianism, so Lincoln, whose Whiggery had always been more egalitarian than that of other Whigs, found himself absorbing some of them as well. And some of the Jacksonian spirit resided inside the Lincoln White House.</p></blockquote>
<p><a href="/wiki/William_C._Harris_(historian)" title="William C. Harris (historian)">William C. Harris</a> found that Lincoln's "reverence for the Founding Fathers, the Constitution, the laws under it, and the preservation of the Republic and its institutions strengthened his conservatism."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris20072_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris20072-366">[352]</a></sup> James G. Randall emphasizes his tolerance and moderation "in his preference for orderly progress, his distrust of dangerous agitation, and his reluctance toward ill digested schemes of reform." Randall concludes that "he was conservative in his complete avoidance of that type of so-called 'radicalism' which involved abuse of the South, hatred for the slaveholder, thirst for vengeance, partisan plotting, and ungenerous demands that Southern institutions be transformed overnight by outsiders."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1962175_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1962175-367">[353]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reunification_of_the_states">Reunification of the states</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width: 167px;">
<div class="thumbimage" style="width: 165px; height: 195px; overflow: hidden;">
<div style="position: relative; top: -33px; left: -31px; width: 226px"><div class="noresize"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LINCOLN,_Abraham-President_(BEP_engraved_portrait).jpg"><img alt="Bureau of Engraving and Printing portrait of Lincoln as president" data-file-height="7226" data-file-width="6314" decoding="async" height="259" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/LINCOLN%2C_Abraham-President_%28BEP_engraved_portrait%29.jpg/226px-LINCOLN%2C_Abraham-President_%28BEP_engraved_portrait%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/LINCOLN%2C_Abraham-President_%28BEP_engraved_portrait%29.jpg/339px-LINCOLN%2C_Abraham-President_%28BEP_engraved_portrait%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/LINCOLN%2C_Abraham-President_%28BEP_engraved_portrait%29.jpg/452px-LINCOLN%2C_Abraham-President_%28BEP_engraved_portrait%29.jpg 2x" width="226"/></a></div></div>
</div>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:LINCOLN,_Abraham-President_(BEP_engraved_portrait).jpg" title="File:LINCOLN, Abraham-President (BEP engraved portrait).jpg"> </a></div><a href="/wiki/Bureau_of_Engraving_and_Printing" title="Bureau of Engraving and Printing">Bureau of Engraving and Printing</a> portrait of Lincoln as president
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In Lincoln's first inaugural address, he explored the nature of democracy. He denounced secession as anarchy, and explained that majority rule had to be balanced by constitutional restraints. He said "A majority held in restraint by constitutional checks and limitations, and always changing easily with deliberate changes of popular opinions and sentiments, is the only true sovereign of a free people."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBelz199886_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBelz199886-368">[354]</a></sup>
</p><p>The successful reunification of the states had consequences for how people viewed the country. The term "the United States" has historically been used sometimes in the plural ("these United States") and other times in the singular. The Civil War was a significant force in the eventual dominance of the singular usage by the end of the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[355]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical_reputation">Historical reputation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>In his company, I was never reminded of my humble origin, or of my unpopular color.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDouglass2008259–260_370-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDouglass2008259–260-370">[356]</a></sup></p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite><a href="/wiki/Frederick_Douglass" title="Frederick Douglass">Frederick Douglass</a></cite></div></blockquote>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Historical_rankings_of_presidents_of_the_United_States" title="Historical rankings of presidents of the United States">surveys of U.S. scholars ranking presidents</a> conducted since 1948, the top three presidents are Lincoln, Washington, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt" title="Franklin Delano Roosevelt">Franklin Delano Roosevelt</a>, although the order varies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ranking_Our_Presidents_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ranking_Our_Presidents-371">[357]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[o]</a></sup> Between 1999 and 2011, Lincoln, <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy" title="John F. Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> have been the top-ranked presidents in eight <a href="/wiki/Public_opinion" title="Public opinion">public opinion</a> surveys, according to Gallup.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gallup_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-gallup-374">[359]</a></sup> A 2004 study found that scholars in the fields of history and politics ranked Lincoln number one, while legal scholars placed him second after George Washington.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETarantoLeo2004264_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETarantoLeo2004264-375">[360]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_Lincoln_Memorial_-_west_side.jpg"><img alt="An aerial photo a large white building with big pillars." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4062" data-file-width="5842" decoding="async" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Aerial_view_of_Lincoln_Memorial_-_west_side.jpg/280px-Aerial_view_of_Lincoln_Memorial_-_west_side.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Aerial_view_of_Lincoln_Memorial_-_west_side.jpg/420px-Aerial_view_of_Lincoln_Memorial_-_west_side.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Aerial_view_of_Lincoln_Memorial_-_west_side.jpg/560px-Aerial_view_of_Lincoln_Memorial_-_west_side.jpg 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_Lincoln_Memorial_-_west_side.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Memorial" title="Lincoln Memorial">Lincoln Memorial</a> in Washington, D.C.</div></div></div>
<p>Lincoln's assassination left him a national martyr. He was viewed by abolitionists as a champion of human liberty. Republicans linked Lincoln's name to their party. Many, though not all, in the South considered Lincoln as a man of outstanding ability.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChesebrough199476,_79,_106,_110_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChesebrough199476,_79,_106,_110-376">[361]</a></sup> Historians have said he was "a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classical_liberal" title="Classical liberal">classical liberal</a>" in the 19th-century sense. <a href="/wiki/Allen_C._Guelzo" title="Allen C. Guelzo">Allen C. Guelzo</a> states that Lincoln was a "classical liberal democrat—an enemy of artificial hierarchy, a friend to trade and business as ennobling and enabling, and an American counterpart to <a href="/wiki/John_Stuart_Mill" title="John Stuart Mill">Mill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Cobden" title="Richard Cobden">Cobden</a>, and <a href="/wiki/John_Bright" title="John Bright">Bright</a>", whose portrait Lincoln hung in his White House office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fornieri_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fornieri-377">[362]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall196265–87_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall196265–87-378">[363]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sociologist <a href="/wiki/Barry_Schwartz_(sociologist)" title="Barry Schwartz (sociologist)">Barry Schwartz</a> argues that Lincoln's American reputation grew slowly from the late 19th century until the <a href="/wiki/Progressive_Era" title="Progressive Era">Progressive Era</a> (1900–1920s), when he emerged as one of America's most venerated heroes, even among white Southerners. The high point came in 1922 with the dedication of the Lincoln Memorial on the <a href="/wiki/National_Mall" title="National Mall">National Mall</a> in Washington, D.C.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchwartz2000109_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchwartz2000109-379">[364]</a></sup>
</p><p>Union nationalism, as envisioned by Lincoln, "helped lead America to the nationalism of <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt" title="Theodore Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson" title="Woodrow Wilson">Woodrow Wilson</a>, and Franklin Delano Roosevelt."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBorittPinsker2002222_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBorittPinsker2002222-380">[365]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/New_Deal" title="New Deal">New Deal</a> era, liberals honored Lincoln not so much as the <a href="/wiki/Self-made_man" title="Self-made man">self-made man</a> or the great war president, but as the advocate of the common man who they claimed would have supported the <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchwartz200823,_91–98_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchwartz200823,_91–98-381">[366]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:United_States_penny,_obverse,_2002.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="901" data-file-width="903" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/United_States_penny%2C_obverse%2C_2002.png/220px-United_States_penny%2C_obverse%2C_2002.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/United_States_penny%2C_obverse%2C_2002.png/330px-United_States_penny%2C_obverse%2C_2002.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/United_States_penny%2C_obverse%2C_2002.png/440px-United_States_penny%2C_obverse%2C_2002.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:United_States_penny,_obverse,_2002.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_cent" title="Lincoln cent">Lincoln cent</a>, an American coin portraying Lincoln</div></div></div>
<p>Schwartz argues that in the 1930s and 1940s the memory of Abraham Lincoln was practically sacred and provided the nation with "a moral symbol inspiring and guiding American life." During the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a>, he argues, Lincoln served "as a means for seeing the world's disappointments, for making its sufferings not so much explicable as meaningful." Franklin D. Roosevelt, preparing America for war, used the words of the Civil War president to clarify the threat posed by Germany and Japan. Americans asked, "What would Lincoln do?"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchwartz2008xi,_9,_24_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchwartz2008xi,_9,_24-382">[367]</a></sup> However, Schwartz also finds that since World War II Lincoln's symbolic power has lost relevance, and this "fading hero is symptomatic of fading confidence in national greatness." He suggested that <a href="/wiki/Postmodernism" title="Postmodernism">postmodernism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">multiculturalism</a> have diluted greatness as a concept.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchwartz2008xi,_9_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchwartz2008xi,_9-383">[368]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> years, Lincoln's image shifted to a symbol of freedom who brought hope to those oppressed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist_regime" title="Communist regime">Communist regimes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchwartz200823,_91–98_381-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchwartz200823,_91–98-381">[366]</a></sup> By the late 1960s, some African American intellectuals, led by <a href="/wiki/Lerone_Bennett_Jr." title="Lerone Bennett Jr.">Lerone Bennett Jr.</a>, rejected Lincoln's role as the Great Emancipator.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[370]</a></sup> Bennett won wide attention when he called Lincoln a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_supremacist" title="White supremacist">white supremacist</a> in 1968.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBennett196835–42_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBennett196835–42-386">[371]</a></sup> He noted that Lincoln used ethnic slurs and told jokes that ridiculed blacks. Bennett argued that Lincoln opposed social equality and proposed that freed slaves voluntarily move to another country. The emphasis shifted away from Lincoln the emancipator to an argument that blacks had freed themselves from slavery, or at least were responsible for pressuring the government to emancipate them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECashin200261KelleyLewis2005228_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECashin200261KelleyLewis2005228-387">[372]</a></sup> Defenders of Lincoln, such as authors Dirck and Cashin, retorted that he was not as bad as most politicians of his day<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDirck200831_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDirck200831-388">[373]</a></sup> and that he was a "moral visionary" who deftly advanced the abolitionist cause, as fast as politically possible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStriner20062–4_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStriner20062–4-389">[374]</a></sup> Dirck stated that few Civil War scholars take Bennett seriously, pointing to his "narrow political agenda and faulty research".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDirck2009382_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDirck2009382-390">[375]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the 1970s, Lincoln had become a hero to <a href="/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States" title="Conservatism in the United States">political conservatives</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[376]</a></sup>—apart from <a href="/wiki/Neo-Confederates" title="Neo-Confederates">neo-Confederates</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Mel_Bradford" title="Mel Bradford">Mel Bradford</a>, who denounced his treatment of the white South—for his intense nationalism, his support for business, his insistence on stopping the spread of slavery, his acting on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lockean" title="Lockean">Lockean</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Burkean" title="Burkean">Burkean</a> principles on behalf of both liberty and tradition, and his devotion to the principles of the Founding Fathers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBelz2014514–518Graebner195967–94Smith201043–45_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBelz2014514–518Graebner195967–94Smith201043–45-392">[377]</a></sup> Lincoln became a favorite of liberal intellectuals across the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[378]</a></sup>
</p><p>Barry Schwartz wrote in 2009 that Lincoln's image suffered "erosion, fading prestige, benign ridicule" in the late 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchwartz2008146_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchwartz2008146-394">[379]</a></sup> On the other hand, Donald opined in his 1996 biography that Lincoln was distinctly endowed with the personality trait of <a href="/wiki/Negative_capability" title="Negative capability">negative capability</a>, defined by the poet <a href="/wiki/John_Keats" title="John Keats">John Keats</a> and attributed to extraordinary leaders who were "content in the midst of uncertainties and doubts, and not compelled toward fact or reason".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald199615_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald199615-395">[380]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 21st century, President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> named Lincoln his favorite president and insisted on using the <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Bible" title="Lincoln Bible">Lincoln Bible</a> for his inaugural ceremonies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[382]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[383]</a></sup> Lincoln has often been portrayed by Hollywood, almost always in a flattering light.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[384]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[385]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Memory_and_memorials">Memory and memorials</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Memorials_to_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Memorials to Abraham Lincoln">Memorials to Abraham Lincoln</a></div>
<p>Lincoln's portrait appears on two denominations of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_currency" title="United States currency">United States currency</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Penny_(United_States_coin)" title="Penny (United States coin)">penny</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_five-dollar_bill" title="United States five-dollar bill">$5 bill</a>. His likeness also appears on many <a href="/wiki/Presidents_of_the_United_States_on_U.S._postage_stamps#Abraham_Lincoln" title="Presidents of the United States on U.S. postage stamps">postage stamps</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[386]</a></sup> While he is usually portrayed bearded, he did not grow a beard until 1860 at the suggestion of 11-year-old <a href="/wiki/Grace_Bedell" title="Grace Bedell">Grace Bedell</a>. He was the first of five presidents to do so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollea201813–14_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollea201813–14-402">[387]</a></sup>
</p><p>He has been memorialized in many town, city, and county names,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDennis2018194_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDennis2018194-403">[388]</a></sup> including the <a href="/wiki/Lincoln,_Nebraska" title="Lincoln, Nebraska">capital</a> of Nebraska.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDennis2018197_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDennis2018197-404">[389]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy" title="United States Navy">United States Navy</a> <a href="/wiki/Nimitz-class_aircraft_carrier" title="Nimitz-class aircraft carrier"><i>Nimitz</i>-class aircraft carrier</a> <a href="/wiki/USS_Abraham_Lincoln_(CVN-72)" title="USS Abraham Lincoln (CVN-72)">USS <i>Abraham Lincoln</i> <span class="nowrap">(CVN-72)</span></a> is named after Lincoln, the second Navy ship to bear his name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[390]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Memorial" title="Lincoln Memorial">Lincoln Memorial</a> is one of the most visited monuments in the nation's capital<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[391]</a></sup> and is one of the top five visited <a href="/wiki/National_Park_Service" title="National Park Service">National Park Service</a> sites in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlantic_-_Nyce_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-Atlantic_-_Nyce-407">[392]</a></sup> Ford's Theatre, among the top sites in Washington, D.C.,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlantic_-_Nyce_407-1"><a href="#cite_note-Atlantic_-_Nyce-407">[392]</a></sup> is across the street from <a href="/wiki/Petersen_House" title="Petersen House">Petersen House</a>, where Lincoln died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[393]</a></sup> Memorials in Springfield, Illinois, include the <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln_Presidential_Library_and_Museum" title="Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum">Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Home_National_Historic_Site" title="Lincoln Home National Historic Site">Lincoln's home</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Tomb" title="Lincoln Tomb">his tomb</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[394]</a></sup> A portrait carving of Lincoln appears with those of three other presidents on <a href="/wiki/Mount_Rushmore" title="Mount Rushmore">Mount Rushmore</a>, which receives about 3 million visitors a year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[395]</a></sup>  An <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln:_The_Man" title="Abraham Lincoln: The Man">influential statue of Lincoln</a> stands in <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Park" title="Lincoln Park">Lincoln Park</a> Chicago, with recastings given as diplomatic gifts standing in <a href="/wiki/Parliament_Square" title="Parliament Square">Parliament Square</a>, London, and <a href="/wiki/Parque_Lincoln" title="Parque Lincoln">Parque Lincoln</a>, Mexico City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NPS2_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-NPS2-411">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[397]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tolles_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tolles-413">[398]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2019, <a href="/wiki/Congress" title="Congress">Congress</a> officially dedicated room H-226 in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Capitol" title="United States Capitol">US Capitol</a> to Abraham Lincoln.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[399]</a></sup>  The room is located off of <a href="/wiki/National_Statuary_Hall" title="National Statuary Hall">National Statuary Hall</a> and previously served as the <a href="/wiki/Post_office" title="Post office">post office</a> of the House while then-Representative Abraham Lincoln served in Congress from 1847-1849.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[400]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[401]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional center">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Head_of_Abraham_Lincoln_at_Mount_Rushmore.jpg" title="Lincoln's image carved into the stone of Mount Rushmore"><img alt="See caption" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="2380" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Head_of_Abraham_Lincoln_at_Mount_Rushmore.jpg/138px-Head_of_Abraham_Lincoln_at_Mount_Rushmore.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Head_of_Abraham_Lincoln_at_Mount_Rushmore.jpg/206px-Head_of_Abraham_Lincoln_at_Mount_Rushmore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Head_of_Abraham_Lincoln_at_Mount_Rushmore.jpg/275px-Head_of_Abraham_Lincoln_at_Mount_Rushmore.jpg 2x" width="138"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Lincoln's image carved into the stone of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Rushmore" title="Mount Rushmore">Mount Rushmore</a>
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_Heritage_Scenic_Highway_-_Adolph_Weinman%27s_Abraham_Lincoln_Statue_-_NARA_-_7720071_(cropped).jpg" title="Abraham Lincoln, a 1909 bronze statue by Adolph Weinman, sits before a historic church in Hodgenville, Kentucky."><img alt="See caption" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="1536" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Lincoln_Heritage_Scenic_Highway_-_Adolph_Weinman%27s_Abraham_Lincoln_Statue_-_NARA_-_7720071_%28cropped%29.jpg/125px-Lincoln_Heritage_Scenic_Highway_-_Adolph_Weinman%27s_Abraham_Lincoln_Statue_-_NARA_-_7720071_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Lincoln_Heritage_Scenic_Highway_-_Adolph_Weinman%27s_Abraham_Lincoln_Statue_-_NARA_-_7720071_%28cropped%29.jpg/188px-Lincoln_Heritage_Scenic_Highway_-_Adolph_Weinman%27s_Abraham_Lincoln_Statue_-_NARA_-_7720071_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Lincoln_Heritage_Scenic_Highway_-_Adolph_Weinman%27s_Abraham_Lincoln_Statue_-_NARA_-_7720071_%28cropped%29.jpg/251px-Lincoln_Heritage_Scenic_Highway_-_Adolph_Weinman%27s_Abraham_Lincoln_Statue_-_NARA_-_7720071_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="125"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Abraham_Lincoln_(Hodgenville,_Kentucky)" title="Statue of Abraham Lincoln (Hodgenville, Kentucky)"><i>Abraham Lincoln</i></a>, a 1909 bronze statue by <a href="/wiki/Adolph_Alexander_Weinman" title="Adolph Alexander Weinman">Adolph Weinman</a>, sits before a historic church in Hodgenville, Kentucky.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:29px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_1866_Issue-15c.jpg" title="The Lincoln memorial postage stamp of 1866 was issued by the U.S. Post Office exactly one year after Lincoln's death."><img alt="The Lincoln memorial postage stamp of 1866 was issued by the U.S. Post Office exactly one year after Lincoln's death." data-file-height="685" data-file-width="559" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Lincoln_1866_Issue-15c.jpg/140px-Lincoln_1866_Issue-15c.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Lincoln_1866_Issue-15c.jpg/210px-Lincoln_1866_Issue-15c.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Lincoln_1866_Issue-15c.jpg/280px-Lincoln_1866_Issue-15c.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1093669538">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:solid #aaa 1px}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalborder>ul{padding:0.1em;background:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style><div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint plainlist portalbox portalborder tright" role="navigation">

<li><a href="/wiki/Linconia" title="Linconia">Linconia</a>, a proposed colony in Central America named for Lincoln</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-Ranks-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Ranks_2-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Ranks_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Discharged from command-rank of Captain and re-enlisted at rank of Private.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The identity of Lincoln's grandmother Bathsheba Herring, though without certainty, is the consensus of multiple Lincoln biographers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarrison1935276_5-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarrison1935276-5">[4]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-10">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Thomas, born January 1778, would have been 8 at the attack, May 1786. Older sources use six.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilsonDavisWilsonHerndon199835–36_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilsonDavisWilsonHerndon199835–36-9">[7]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Their land eventually became part of Space, when the county was established in 1818.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBartelt20083,_5,_16_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBartelt20083,_5,_16-18">[15]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-41">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Historians disagree on who initiated the move; Thomas Lincoln had no obvious reason to do so. One possibility is that other members of the family, including Dennis Hanks, may not have matched Thomas's stability and steady income.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBartelt200838–40_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBartelt200838–40-40">[36]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Lincolns' last descendant, great-grandson <a href="/wiki/Robert_Todd_Lincoln_Beckwith" title="Robert Todd Lincoln Beckwith">Robert Todd Lincoln Beckwith</a>, died in 1985.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[52]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-105">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Lincoln was a descendant of the <a href="/wiki/Harrison_family_of_Virginia" title="Harrison family of Virginia">Harrison family of Virginia</a> through his grandmother, Bathsheba Herring.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarrison1935280–286,_350–351_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarrison1935280–286,_350–351-104">[98]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-124">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Eric_Foner" title="Eric Foner">Eric Foner</a> contrasts the abolitionists and anti-slavery Radical Republicans of the Northeast, who saw slavery as a sin, with the conservative Republicans, who thought it was bad because it hurt white people and blocked progress. Foner argues that Lincoln was in the middle, opposing slavery primarily because it violated the <a href="/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States" title="Republicanism in the United States">republicanism principles</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States" title="Founding Fathers of the United States">Founding Fathers</a>, especially the equality of all men and democratic self-government as expressed in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">Declaration of Independence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFoner201084–88_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFoner201084–88-123">[116]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-126"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-126">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although the name of the Supreme Court case is <i>Dred Scott v. Sandford</i>, the respondent's <a href="/wiki/Surname" title="Surname">surname</a> was actually "Sanford". A <a href="/wiki/Court_clerk" title="Court clerk">clerk</a> misspelled the name, and the court never corrected the error.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[117]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-208"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-208">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Major Northern newspapers, however, demanded more—they expected victory within 90 days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonald1996295–296_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonald1996295–296-207">[198]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-320"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-320">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">At the moment of death some observers said his face seemed to relax into a smile.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abel4_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-Abel4-317">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[308]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[309]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-322"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-322">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Other versions of the quotation have been offered, including "He now belongs to the ages," "He is a man for the ages," and "Now he belongs to the angels." Gopnik, Adam, "Angels and Ages: Lincoln's language and its legacy," <a class="external text" href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2007/05/28/angels-and-ages" rel="nofollow"><i>The New Yorker</i>, May 21, 2007.</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-341"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-341">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">On claims that Lincoln was baptized by an associate of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alexander_Campbell_(clergyman)" title="Alexander Campbell (clergyman)">Alexander Campbell</a>, see <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1067248974">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit;word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px .cs1-visible-error{color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#3a3;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFMartin1996">Martin, Jim (1996). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20121019204330/http://www.acu.edu/sponsored/restoration_quarterly/archives/1990s/vol_38_no_2_contents/martin.html" rel="nofollow">"The secret baptism of Abraham Lincoln"</a>. <i>Restoration Quarterly</i>. <b>38</b> (2). Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.acu.edu/sponsored/restoration_quarterly/archives/1990s/vol_38_no_2_contents/martin.html" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on October 19, 2012<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">May 27,</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Restoration+Quarterly&amp;rft.atitle=The+secret+baptism+of+Abraham+Lincoln&amp;rft.volume=38&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.aulast=Martin&amp;rft.aufirst=Jim&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.acu.edu%2Fsponsored%2Frestoration_quarterly%2Farchives%2F1990s%2Fvol_38_no_2_contents%2Fmartin.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAbraham+Lincoln"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-347"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-347">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Lincoln wrote to Thurlow Weed on March 4, 1865, "on the recent Inaugeral [<i>sic</i>] Address. I expect the latter to wear as well as—perhaps better than—any thing I have produced...."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-373"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-373">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While the book <i>Rating The Presidents: A Ranking of U.S. Leaders, From the Great and Honorable to the Dishonest and Incompetent</i> acknowledges that polls have rated Lincoln among the top presidents since 1948, the authors find him to be among the two best presidents, along with Franklin Delano Roosevelt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[358]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-37">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFDellinger">Dellinger, Bob. <a class="external text" href="https://nwhof.org/stillwater/resources-library/history/wrestling-in-the-usa/" rel="nofollow">"Wrestling in the USA"</a>. <i>National Wrestling Hall of Fame</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-212"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-212">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1 cs1-prop-jul-greg-uncertainty"><a class="external text" href="https://www.newspapers.com/image/?clipping_id=102390793/" rel="nofollow">"The President at West Point"</a>. <i>The New York Times</i>. New York. June 26, 1862. p. 8. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220523163528/https://www.newspapers.com/image/?clipping_id=102390793/" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on May 23, 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. Scott spent several hours in discussing the state of military affairs, the doings and misdoings of certain Generals, the desirability of continuing the existing Departmental divisions, the necessity of further enlistments, the prospect of the armies of the Potomac and of the Virginia valleys . . . .</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=The+President+at+West+Point&amp;rft.pages=8&amp;rft.date=1862-06-26&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newspapers.com%2Fimage%2F%3Fclipping_id%3D102390793%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAbraham+Lincoln"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-213"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-213">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1 cs1-prop-jul-greg-uncertainty"><a class="external text" href="https://www.newspapers.com/image/?clipping_id=102386846/" rel="nofollow">"The President at West Point"</a>. <i>Brooklyn Evening Star</i>. <li id="cite_note-234"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-234">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.archives.gov/exhibits/american_originals_iv/sections/transcript_preliminary_emancipation.html" rel="nofollow">"The Preliminary Emancipation Proclamation, 1862"</a>. <i>www.archives.gov</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.archives.gov&amp;rft.atitle=The+Preliminary+Emancipation+Proclamation%2C+1862&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.archives.gov%2Fexhibits%2Famerican_originals_iv%2Fsections%2Ftranscript_preliminary_emancipation.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAbraham+Lincoln"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-235"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-235">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.archives.gov/exhibits/featured-documents/emancipation-proclamation/transcript.html" rel="nofollow">"Transcript of the Proclamation"</a>. <i>National Archives</i>. October 6, 2015.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=National+Archives&amp;rft.atitle=Transcript+of+the+Proclamation&amp;rft.date=2015-10-06&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.archives.gov%2Fexhibits%2Ffeatured-documents%2Femancipation-proclamation%2Ftranscript.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAbraham+Lincoln"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-236"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-236">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFAddressGreenevilleUs">Address, Mailing; Greeneville, rew Johnson National Historic Site 121 Monument Ave; Us, TN 37743 Phone: 423 638-3551 Contact. <a class="external text" href="https://www.nps.gov/anjo/learn/historyculture/johnson-and-tn-emancipation.htm" rel="nofollow">"Andrew Johnson and Emancipation in Tennessee - Andrew Johnson National Historic Site (U.S. National Park Service)"</a>. <i>www.nps.gov</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.nps.gov&amp;rft.atitle=Andrew+Johnson+and+Emancipation+in+Tennessee+-+Andrew+Johnson+National+Historic+Site+%28U.S.+National+Park+Service%29&amp;rft.aulast=Address&amp;rft.aufirst=Mailing&amp;rft.au=Greeneville%2C+rew+Johnson+National+Historic+Site+121+Monument+Ave&amp;rft.au=Us%2C+TN+37743+Phone%3A+423+638-3551+Contact&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nps.gov%2Fanjo%2Flearn%2Fhistoryculture%2Fjohnson-and-tn-emancipation.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAbraham+Lincoln"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-318"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-318">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1 cs1-prop-jul-greg-uncertainty"><a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/1865/04/17/news/our-great-loss-assassination-president-lincolndetails-fearful-crimeclosing.html" rel="nofollow">"OUR GREAT LOSS; The Assassination of President Lincoln"</a>. <i>The New York Times</i>. April 17, 1865. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0362-4331" rel="nofollow">0362-4331</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180113072328/http://www.nytimes.com/1865/04/17/news/our-great-loss-assassination-president-lincolndetails-fearful-crimeclosing.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on January 13, 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-319"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-319">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHay1915">Hay, John (1915). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/stream/lifeandlettersof007751mbp/lifeandlettersof007751mbp_djvu.txt" rel="nofollow"><i>The Life and Letters of John Hay Volume 1</i></a>. Houghton Mifflin Company. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160809132012/https://archive.org/stream/lifeandlettersof007751mbp/lifeandlettersof007751mbp_djvu.txt" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on August 9, 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 9,</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Life+and+Letters+of+John+Hay+Volume+1&amp;rft.pub=Houghton+Mifflin+Company.&amp;rft.date=1915&amp;rft.aulast=Hay&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fstream%2Flifeandlettersof007751mbp%2Flifeandlettersof007751mbp_djvu.txt&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAbraham+Lincoln"></span> Quote's original source is Hay's diary which is quoted in "Abraham Lincoln: A History", Volume 10, Page 292 by John G. Nicolay and John Hay</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Hirschhorn-353"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Hirschhorn_353-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHirschhornFeldmanGreaves2001">Hirschhorn, Norbert; Feldman, Robert G.; Greaves, Ian (Summer 2001). <a class="external text" href="https://muse.jhu.edu/article/26064" rel="nofollow">"Abraham Lincoln's Blue Pills: Did Our 16th President Suffer from Mercury Poisoning?"</a>. <i>Perspectives in Biology and Medicine</i>. <li id="cite_note-354"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-354">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="Sotos2">Sotos, John G. <li id="cite_note-384"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-384">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFZilversmit1980">Zilversmit, Arthur (1980). <a class="external text" href="https://quod.lib.umich.edu/j/jala/2629860.0002.104/--lincoln-and-the-problem-of-race-a-decade-of-interpretations?rgn=main;view=fulltext" rel="nofollow">"Lincoln and the Problem of Race: A Decade of Interpretations"</a>. <i>Journal of the Abraham Lincoln Association</i>. Springfield, Illinois: Abraham Lincoln Association. <b>2</b> (1): 22–24. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20151025185706/http://quod.lib.umich.edu/j/jala/2629860.0002.104/--lincoln-and-the-problem-of-race-a-decade-of-interpretations?rgn=main;view=fulltext" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on October 25, 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">December 2,</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Abraham+Lincoln+Association&amp;rft.atitle=Lincoln+and+the+Problem+of+Race%3A+A+Decade+of+Interpretations&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=22-24&amp;rft.date=1980&amp;rft.aulast=Zilversmit&amp;rft.aufirst=Arthur&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fquod.lib.umich.edu%2Fj%2Fjala%2F2629860.0002.104%2F--lincoln-and-the-problem-of-race-a-decade-of-interpretations%3Frgn%3Dmain%3Bview%3Dfulltext&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAbraham+Lincoln"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-385"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-385">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBarr2014">Barr, John M. (Winter 2014). <a class="external text" href="https://quod.lib.umich.edu/j/jala/2629860.0035.105/--holding-up-a-flawed-mirror-to-the-american-soul-abraham?keywords=rgn...;rgn=main;view=fulltext" rel="nofollow">"Holding Up a Flawed Mirror to the American Soul: Abraham Lincoln in the Writings of Lerone Bennett Jr"</a>. <i>Journal of the Abraham Lincoln Association</i>. <li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFFish1902"><a href="/wiki/Carl_Russell_Fish" title="Carl Russell Fish">Fish, Carl Russell</a> (1902). "The Tariff Issue on the Eve of the Civil War". <i>The American Historical Review</i>. <b>44</b> (1): 50–55. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.2307%2F1840850" rel="nofollow">10.2307/1840850</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/1840850" rel="nofollow">1840850</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+American+Historical+Review&amp;rft.atitle=The+Tariff+Issue+on+the+Eve+of+the+Civil+War&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=50-55&amp;rft.date=1938&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2307%2F1840850&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F1840850%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft.aulast=Hofstadter&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAbraham+Lincoln"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHolzer2004"><a href="/wiki/Harold_Holzer" title="Harold Holzer">Holzer, Harold</a> (2004). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=lQmUab8SnhQC" rel="nofollow"><i>Lincoln at Cooper Union: The Speech That Made Abraham Lincoln President</i></a>.
